content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												Telltale has done it again they made a badass adventure game set in Bill Willingham's world of Fables (It's a graphic novel series that you can find on http://www.billwillingham.com/ if you want more mature stories) & I'll try my best to explain the game. WARNING IF YOU HATE SPOILERS, PROSTITUTION, SEEING YOUR FAVORITE FAIRYTALE CHARACTERS SUFFER, POLICE BRUTALITY (Mostly Bigby) & ALL SORTS OF OTHER♥♥♥♥♥♥HAPPEN THEN THIS GAME AIN'T FOR YOU!!!!!!So our game begins with the big bad wolf himself protecting most of the childhood fairytale characters we all know & love while trying to keep his cool towards the unbearable NPCs like the corrupt mayor Ichabod Crane for example but the♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan when one ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ named Faith a.k.a Donkeyskin Girl (It's a fable you can read off here http://www.kidsgen.com/fables_and_fairytales/donkeyskin.htm on this website) has her head laying on the front entrance of Bigby's apartment. Devastated by this tragedy Bigby prepares for his quest to find the culprit behind this terrible crime with the help of his old friend Snow White (He also has a crush on her & who wouldn't she may be animated but those♥♥♥♥♥♥& warm personality can drive any man mad with lust *howls at the moon*) while Bigby finally gets his violent personality back like any badass should (His past is really sad if you read the Winter Wolf fable & probably one of the main reasons he uses violence to solve his problems) to start wrecking havoc on any liars that cover up for the bad guys.From rampage to rampage (I won't go into detail because Bigby fights a lot of people) Bigby & Snow discover that a long crime war has been around for centuries started by Fabletown's professional mob boss The Crooked Man (If you paid attention in school there was a nursery rhyme called "There Was A Crooked Man" which is the same crooked man from the rhyme brought to life by Mr. Willingham) who is obviously the biggest piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥from using scare tactics on his hired help, getting other fables like Tweedle Dee & Dum to do his dirty work, Stealing from the poor, Corruption in the government (Crane was in charge of that) & lots of other crimes that would get you executed.Shocked by this news Bigby yet acts more of a badass to find proof related to all the crimes to catch the biggest fish in the sea (Violence included). After finding proof, killing the Crooked Man's henchman, capturing the mob boss himself, got the crowd supporting Bigby at the trial & punishing Crooked Man order is restored in FableTown so Bigby can finally relax for now. If Bigby wanted to he would have celebrated & maybe get lucky with Snow but we'll save that for another time we'll just let Bigby Drink & Smoke alone. (I hope you enjoyed my version of the story since I can't explain everything about the game)Pros:1. Badass Main Character2. Good Story3. Mature4. Depressing atmosphere5. Set in a comic book universe6. Believable emotions7. Memorable characters (Also dead ones lol)8. The game acts like a prequel to the comic book series9. Interesting character background stories you can read off the game menuCons:1. Some people may despise the Quick Time Events or how simplified the game is since point & click games have a history of being hard (I'm talking about the ones in the 90s & 80s)Overall if you like what you read then give some money to Telltale so they can make another game set in the Fable Universe & leave some feedback if I missed anything.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												I'm a huge fan of The Walking Dead Telltale games, and, being a little morose when I'd completed them, I bought this on a whim whilst it was on sale for a few pounds. And then of course, I never looked at it again for a year or two. During a boring, slightly hungover Sunday, I decided to dig it out and give it a try.  I have absolutely no interest in superheroes, comics or even games set in a grimy, dark urban settings, so it was to my complete surprise that I absolutely loved this game! The game is, in simple terms, about a bunch of fables, myths or otherwise legendary characters who are all living an area of New York as their 'real' selves. Bigby, the anti-hero, is based on the Big Bad Wolf, and he's a sort of sheriff character, trying to rid the streets of crime from the likes of Tweedledee and Tweedledum, the Crooked Man and Georgie Porgie (who's a right a**e, let me tell you). Sh*t goes down, and Bigby ends up having to solve a murder linked directly to him, alongside Snow White, the assistant to the Mayor.  The gameplay is very much like TWD games, with point and click action, so if you liked those games, you're on to a winner with this one. The story is dramatic and really quite dark, with false paths, red herrings and unexpected developments throughout. It was an unusual story, and this game was one of those that stuck with me for days afterwards. Of course, being a Telltale adventure game, it makes you feel terrible about any choices you make. For any fan of TWD series and story driven adventure games, this is one you can't miss. It is well worth the full price, so wait for the sales and get it for a few pounds. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												The Wolf Among us is a story based detective mystery. It is very similar to the Walking Dead in base mechanics like a heavy reliance on quick time events and plenty of dialogue.  The game takes place in New York, in a certain section in town where fairly tale characters live and appear human due to an expensive magic they have to acquire unless they want to be sent The Farm which is said to be like a prison of sorts. You play as Sheriff Bigby who was a former murder and is now tasked with keeping the  fantasy tale characters know as Fables safe. Bigby has quite a temper so even if you try to play as a saint in this game he will occasionally still be a jerk which adds to his character. This is not a game for kids. The cute talking animals are quite foul mouthed and there is plenty of pretty graphic violence and heavy subjects during your investigations.Gameplay is bare-bones. Fight scenes are just Quick time events as I've mentioned though they are pretty fun to watch since some Fables have super strength and all of them are very resilient to damage which leads to some pretty violent lengthy fights.  When given control of the character you can interact with a few predetermined items and talk with characters. There are never really any puzzles or actual investigating which I found rather disappointing considering the plot revolves around mystery. Most of the leads can be found simply by talking or plain assaulting a suspect. It is very linear and when you are given a choice where to go most of the times you will go to the place you didn't pick afterwards anyways. Your choices to play as a “man” chasing redemption through justice or a psychotic tormentor are pretty cool since sometimes you just really want to maim someone instead of arresting them.The artstyle in this game is superb. The town looks really run down and the neon soaked streets just add so much charm. Cell shading really fits the game perfectly. Everywhere you journey to is filled with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, odd mystical creatures or plane unsavory hostile sorts. You never really meet any one normal and only see regular humans on the background in some scenes, never interacting with them. When Fables show their true forms more often than not they look horrifying but lucky your character Bigby is more than capable to take most of them on. Also there is nudity and pretty detailed gore which fits the gritty tone of the game but once again I must say do not be fooled by the screenshots thinking this is a game for children.The sound track is amazing and definitely one of my favorites of 2014. It is a kind of fusion between moody, techno and mystery which fit the game like a glove. Voice acting is pretty good as well which is a must for such a heavily dialogue driven game. One thing that caught me off guard was the same actor that plays Clementine in the Walking Dead plays a child frog called Toad Jr. Having just played the walking dead it was plain odd seeing a frog talk while Clementine's voice comes out of its mouth. Nothing wrong with that, just something I found funny that I wanted to mention. Sounds effects are pretty satisfying too. Sounds great when you throw or get thrown several feet through the air and break a wall and its to the appeal of the super hero like fight scenes.As to be expected from Telltale the story is the best part of the game. You never really know what to expect since the world is so odd and unique. You start off investigating a murder but as to be expected things quickly become much more complicated. It starts off pretty strong but the villains don't really do anything else bad after the first episode which makes you lose some interest as you simply investigate because it is your character's job and to play the game you bought instead of being actually invested in the mystery and the culprit. Don't get me wrong it's a decent enough tale but quickly loses steam and it takes quite awhile to regain some. It's just too bad that a mystery game ends on a cliffhanger which leaves you completely unsatisfied. Characters themselves are all memorable with very different personalities and oddities. In the end I'd say this is a very enjoyable game for those looking for a good story and an odd world that you will remember long after you beat the game.  I did experience a glitch twice that made me go exit to the main menu due to not being able to pick any choices in dialogue but those all happened right after a quick save and hence was a very minor issue.  Don't be expecting to be using brainpower during this title though. It is heavily on rails and you will discover everything through talking and quick time events. If you are fine with that then I can see no reason not to suggest this game. This a very unique experience that should be tried by anyone that loves story based games.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												The Wolf Among Us is the shortest Telltale adventure game series I've played so far but it's turned out to be one of my favourites. Its unique setting with downtrodden fairy tale characters living in an 80s New York (courtesy of Bill Willingham's Fables) seems to be a perfect match for an adventure game - or a visual novel with Quick Time Events (which I believe is a more accurate description of Telltale's adventure games from the past couple of years). Is it better than The Walking Dead? I personally think so, but only because I like solving murder mysteries. Both games are good in their own right but while one explores the human condition against a backdrop of zombie apocalypse, the other provides a grittier, seedier epilogue to fairy tale characters we grew up learning about as kids.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												I'm a huge fan of The Walking Dead Telltale games, and, being a little morose when I'd completed them, I bought this on a whim whilst it was on sale for a few pounds. And then of course, I never looked at it again for a year or two. During a boring, slightly hungover Sunday, I decided to dig it out and give it a try.  I have absolutely no interest in superheroes, comics or even games set in a grimy, dark urban settings, so it was to my complete surprise that I absolutely loved this game! The game is, in simple terms, about a bunch of fables, myths or otherwise legendary characters who are all living an area of New York as their 'real' selves. Bigby, the anti-hero, is based on the Big Bad Wolf, and he's a sort of sheriff character, trying to rid the streets of crime from the likes of Tweedledee and Tweedledum, the Crooked Man and Georgie Porgie (who's a right a**e, let me tell you). Sh*t goes down, and Bigby ends up having to solve a murder linked directly to him, alongside Snow White, the assistant to the Mayor.  The gameplay is very much like TWD games, with point and click action, so if you liked those games, you're on to a winner with this one. The story is dramatic and really quite dark, with false paths, red herrings and unexpected developments throughout. It was an unusual story, and this game was one of those that stuck with me for days afterwards. Of course, being a Telltale adventure game, it makes you feel terrible about any choices you make. For any fan of TWD series and story driven adventure games, this is one you can't miss. It is well worth the full price, so wait for the sales and get it for a few pounds. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Surprisingly good  (if short) visual novel/interactive movie.Honestly - I haven't even expected it to be good, my last Telltale game was Sam and Max, and it wasn't even decent in comparsion to original game. But it seems that developers learned their lesson, tightened up their writing, and finally have gotten familiar with their cellshaded engine.I'm not a big fan of comic series which this game is based upon, but authors managed to stay true to original characterisation and even given some supporting characters more depth. Voice acting is also surprised me, while not phenomenal, it was really good.So on a plus side we have:1) graphics - it really looks like a comic, and some scenes are screenshot-worthy;2) voice acting - like I said, not phenomenal, but surprisingly good; 3) plot - it's hard to describe it and avoid spoilers at the same time, but I almost wish that it would have been AU instead of prequel; it stays true to characterization and setting of the original Fables, and simultaniously gives surprising depth to secondary, and, to lesser extent, main characters.The game has a few minuses though:1) length (I realize that it's an episodic game, but an episode should be more "meaty", IMO);2) console controls (it really shows that the games were developed with a controller in mind, and not mouse + keyboard; mouse acceleration is awfull, and controls are sometimes awkward);3) the fact that it's a prequel (if they are to stay true to the story, then they just can't kill characters which later will appear in the comics, it somewhat ruins the element of surprise);4) music, especially the main theme (most music in game is forgettable, but "DUN... TU-DUN. DUN... TU-DUN. tim-dam-dam." main theme is just grating).****/*****

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Even though the horror genre is generally lost on me -- especially zombie fiction -- I'm a huge fan of Telltale's The Walking Dead. The writing, particularly dialogue and characterization, really sets the bar about as high as it can possibly get in video games.I was naturally excited to play The Wolf Among Us, though I decided to wait until the summer sale this year to play it so I could experience it in a binge, like I did when I played The Walking Dead Season One last summer.This series lives up to the high standard set by The Walking Dead, and it appeals even more to me than that series does. The characters are fantastic, the dialogue is expertly written and even quite humorous at times, though the story itself is really quite dark. The characters are all very relatable, and they've got their own issues they're dealing with. At the core of the story is the conflict between who people are and their struggle between their nature and who they ultimately wish to be. It's deep stuff, and the fact that the game is populated with a number of very real personalities makes it hit all the more harder. I particularly liked characters like Woody and Gren; people who come off as your typical villains when first introduced but eventually develop into fully rounded characters with very real flaws, should you allow them to. And, of course, Bigby. Though he ultimately is what you make him, I found that each path you could potentially take is a totally fleshed out, meaningful one. Kudos to the writers, because producing that kind of a narrative can't be an easy thing to design a video game around.The gameplay is pretty sparse, just like it was in The Walking Dead. All quicktime events, with some very stripped-down '90s style point-and-click adventure exploration thrown in as well. I could understand how that may turn some people off, but if you're here for story and characterization (as I am) then it shouldn't bother you much. This game doesn't shy away from what it's strengths are to fit other expectations. It's a story-driven experience, first and foremost, and it's not self conscious about that, which is relieving. I think that trying to shoehorn in some shooting or deeper gameplay would have just distracted from its strengths.The art style is, at its core, the same as The Walking Dead. But the color palette here is spruced up in various shades of warm oranges, neon reds and pinks, and cooler purples. Nothing is really gray or brown. The streets are a cold slate, buildings mimicing the streets, with glowing yellow windows throughout the buildings. Most of the game is set at night, and the artists are obviously shooting for a noir feel, which is helped along by a pretty solid soundtrack. While the basic art style is familiar to Telltale's other efforts, I have to say that it's much improved from the drabness that I felt hurt The Walking Dead. This is a really, really fun game to look at, and though the writing is utterly fantastic, it doesn't have to rely only on that to keep it standing like The Walking Dead did.If you're a fan of Telltale's The Walking Dead, you already know that you should probably buy this. If you're unfamiliar with that title, but you're interested in a strong narrative with a good atmospheric feel, then I can't recommend this game enough. I'm really enjoying it, and I can't wait to play the finale this upcoming Tuesday. But if you're looking for more action, or a more "gamey" game, then you'll probably want to look elsewhere.And man, I really can't wait for their adaptation of Game Of Thrones.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Absolutely amazing game, from start to finish. The story is gripping, the art style is eye-catching, and the voice acting is superb. There are a few odd glitches though. Whenever Steam pops up an achievement notification, it's always during a loading screen and it can make the loading process lag. Three times when this happened, it glitched out the game to where it would skip one or more scenes, immediately thrust me into a dialogue choice, and every option would be blank. Thankfully, the autosave feature is well-implemented, so I can just return to the start menu, continue the story, and proceed as normal. One other odd thing is that in many of the action sequences, if you are playing with a 360 controller, if a prompt comes up to press the right trigger (or vice versa) you can hit the left trigger and it still registers as being the correct button. This isn't necessarily a negative, since many of these instances give you barely any time to react, it's just kinda weird.Overall, 12/10 game. Would slap Toad again.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												The Wolf Among Us is filled to the brim with choices and some of these are really important. It is something I have not experienced before, not on this scale. The Walking Dead is not even close. what really intensifies the decision making is the protagonist of Bigby Wolf. A crude anti-hero that you can role play a bit with. During my first playthrough, I chose a direct route, I had the opportunity to violence when it became so - and the blood flowed. A private investigator got a taste of my fist, another man's face I introduced into a glass bottle and then I tore an arm off. Because I'm the big bad wolf.As the rhythmic music flows, I wander aimlessly around while dark figures pass me by. My white shirt is rumpled and unkempt, with sleeves rolled-up. My black tie is loose, but I do not care in the slightest. The neon purple lights cast sharp shadows on me and framing my bitter facial expression. Then I fall into the darkness, my eyes shimmering yellow for a moment. I lead the cigarette to my lips and takes a puff: it brightens up my face ... My name is Bigby Wolf and I'm Fable Towns sheriff. It all reminds me of the series Once Upon a Time. We are in a city populated by mythical beings disguised as ordinary people - refugees from the city that obviously is not quite as it was told to me as a small child. Fable Town was a promised new beginning but the oh so familiar bureaucracy is hard on the less fortunate. It is a painful story that already after the first episode feels hopeless. No happy ending in sight, just dark storm clouds.The Wolf Among Us is an interactive story where the gameplay takes a back seat . Even more than in Telltale Games last Games, The Walking Dead. Most time will be spent in the dialogues and quick time events, the fact is that the game is full of them. In such a dialogue driven games, it is essential that both the voice actors and the script is good. With a broad smile, I can say that Telltale Games has outdone themselves many times over. Nothing sounds contrived, it is an exceptional performance.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												The Wolf Among Us is a thrilling action adventure based on the award winning Comic book series "Fables". In Fables all the figures from your childhood, like Snow White, Red Riding Hood and many many more came two the Mundie (non-magic) world during the 'Exodus' to find a better live. In the Homelands they suffered surpression, death, enprisonment. But can they solve the problems of a everyday human in Fabletown, NY?You follow Bigby Wolf (the big bad wolf), detective and protector of Fabletown, while he uncovers the mysteries behind a murdered prostitude, he also tries to leave behind his past as one of the major villians in the Homelands. But is both achievable?Telltale has yet again created a very unique game with a very immersive and dark story about Power, Poverty and Emotions. Positiv+ Dark and thrilling story+ While being "rather" short it does not feel as something is lacking. Quality over quantity ;)+ Talltales unique art style/graphics+ likeable characters + the decisions you make will have an impact on how the story unfolds and how the others will react to your presenceNegativ- missing gameplay like puzzles or riddles like in other adventures- a lot of Quick-Time-Events (QTE's)What to expect from TWAU?:You can expect a thrilling detective/noir story which will get you really excited! But if you are looking for a "real" game with "complex" game mechanics, puzzles ect. you will be dissappointed. If you played "The Walking Dead" and are familiar to Telltales work and liked it, then you will definitly like this game too! Now with all episodes, so no forced breaks, you will find it hard to not play it through at once!In Numbers: 85/100 Points

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Telltale strikes again with a beautiful adaptation of the comic series Fables, and the result is mesmerizing. If you love fairytales retelling and film noir mood, you'll love this game. You play as Bigby - nickname for the Big Bad Wolf - the sheriff in charge of the community of Fables, and you start right off the hook with a murder to resolve. The characters, the story, the humour, everything is delightful and I can guarantee you'll love seeing your favorite fairytale figures in a modern setting and how they have adapted to fit into the human world. As for the gameplay, it's all about the story: the choices you make shape the events unfolding and the reactions of the people around you, so there's a dozen of possible outcomes and dialogues you can trigger depending on how you react and how you answer. All in all, a very good game, and definitely one of my favorite these days.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
UPD: Updated for season's finale. Also added a quick TWAU vs TWD comparison, in case anybody is curious.What a beauty.  Excellent writing, art-direction and voice acting, as expected of Telltale. There's absolutely no reason for me to not recommend this to the fans of Telltale's episodic games, or otherwise anyone else interested in what this is all about. Well, unless you're for some reason not fond of the visual style Telltale's been using, can't stand the copious amounts of cartoony gore, or simply hate fairy tales, except this one definitely lacks a happy ending.Speaking from an artist's perspective, The Wolf Among Us blows The Walking Dead completely out of the water in terms of visual narration (well, we're obviously not talking a brown and muddy zombie apocalypse here), it's a lot more colorful and cinematographic, and the attention to detail in some shots is mindblowing - I could barely prevent myself from hitting F12 every time another pretty picture popped up on my screen.Having previously never read the Fables comics that the game is based on, I cannot speak for the faithfulness of the adaptation, but I can assure you that Telltale's writers took great care that the player/reader never gets lost in the story: you don't have to resort to looking up information in order to familiarize yourself with ANY of the characters, or the setting.It's very difficult to speak about the story without spoiling it one way or another, so let me just draw a quick comparison of this game to The Walking Dead one:- More action. Game is packed to the gills with quick time events. Expect a lot of frantic button mashing, especially when you're not expecting it.- More gore. TWAU is a game practically soaked in blood. You'd think TWD would be more gory due to the whole Zombie Apocalypse business going on, but it makes perfect sense in the end as TWD takes a far more realistic approach. TWAU? Expect fountains of blood gushing out. On top of a pile of torn off limbs. It's okay, it'll all heal back anyway! Now let's do it again!- More talk. Remember that this game is a hardboiled detective drama. I wouldn't say it has puzzle elements per se, but you do get to conduct a few interrogations and listen to some teary-eyed claims, which is a welcome change of pace from ripping people's limbs off and beating them to a bloody pulp with said limbs. Or vice versa.- More choices. Don't get me wrong, the game still does not allow you complete freedom, but the impact of your actions/words feels quite a bit more severe than in TWD. Game continuously forces you to choose between several options, thus adding quite a bit of replayability value. And that's great.All in all, it's quite a thrilling ride, and, considering its ending, I'm fairly sure we're not yet done with this story... Not even one bit.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												The Wolf Among Us is a game I never really expected much from, but was completely blown away. I will even admittedly say that I may have even enjoyed this series more than TellTale's famous The Walking Dead series.--Final thoughts at the bottom--GameplayThe game play is reminiscent to TellTales other adventure games. You progress through the story by investigating areas to find useful information or a way of proceding to the next area. Their is no complex puzzles or anything to get you stuck as the game is heavily story related so it tries to keep you progressing. Most of the gameplay is about carefully choosing your response to conversations or story event where you must choose between doing X or doing Y. Quicktime events fill in alot of the action parts and add to the intensity.GraphicsThe cell shaded art style fits perfectly into this world they have created. The characters are well drawn and animated, some feel very recognizable. The facial movements and body movements look good, however some people still seem to walk like they have a stick up their butt(This is an issue I have with all TellTale games). The world they have created sets the perfect setting for how the story takes place. The amount of detail they went into on some of the level design is very well done, even in places you arent around for very long. Its nice to see them still put the detail in to make this feel like a live breathing world.AudioThe sound is done very well in The Wolf Among Us. The background noise and ambience was well done. The music is superb for the style they are going for in this game. The theme song kinda reminds me of Farcry 3: Blood Dragon music. The ingame music was very good at setting the mood for the events happening as well as for the areas you were exploring.The voice over work is phenomenal and is what brings this story to life. The voices chosen for each character fit their rolls perfectly. Not once did I hear any voice that I thought to myself "that doesn't fit". The emotions are portrayed very well through their voices and sucks the player into the story. Top notch voice acting all around.StoryThe story is where this game really shines. I must admit I was never really interested in this game, nor did I really here to much about it, other than "Its good". So I went in knowing nothing about the plot or anything. Wow was I blown away by what I experienced.It takes place in a place known as "Fabletown" which is a small community of fables built on the outskirts of a real world city(I believe its New York). This community is build up of Fables who have left "The woodlands" and have moved into city to live in a real society. However when murders start happening, fabletown turns to terror. You, Bigby Wolf, AKA the big bad wolf, being the sheriff must hunt down and get to the bottom of whoever is behind it. One way or Another. This is The Wolf Among Us's biggest feature. The choices. Every choice you make in this game effects the story severely, even more than TellTales other games. In the walking dead when you madea choice it always felt like no matter what you did it would still end up being the same result, however the wolf among us does the opposite. Every choice effects how people in fabletown view you, which in turn effects trust, reliability, story arc changes and much more. You begin to really care about the characters. You begin to take more time with decisions, knowing that what you do could make characters love or hate you and this could effect how useful they are to you down the line. The story progresses very fluently and keeps you wanting to know more. Their are loads of plot twists that will keep your mind bumbling for more answers. Just when you think you got it figured out, *BAM!!* plot twist. my only complaint about the story was that it was rather short, I played through all 5 episodes in less than 8hrs.Final thoughtsAfter going into this game knowing nothing about it other than "its good", I must say I was blown away by the world they created, and The story had me hooked and thinking about it even when I wasnt playing. The way this game makes you care for its characters is incredible and the obsolutely phenomenal voice over work brings them to life with a voice. The animation and level design is gorgeously done in TellTale's signature cell shaded art and everything plays very smooth with a smooth looking framerate, which is I know alot of problem had with the first season of the walking dead. If you are looking for a game with a unique world and setting, with an amazing story. Then you will love the Wolf Among Us. If you are on the fence about this game, its definetly worth the buy. For a game I wasnt expecting much out of, I must say I think this may be my favourite game created by TellTale(Yes even better than the walking dead).

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Anyone else getting this awkward feeling Telltale Games has a really objectionable stance towards tangible gameplay? They continue with their steady decline away from it in the effort to focus on storytelling instead, as if the two are mutually exclusive somehow in their mind. Having said that, The Wolf Among Us manages to deliver a compelling story, if a bit blase for the fans of the detective genre, which manages to keep you engaged and its structure as a mystery seems to work really well with the now alredy tried-and-true episodic format. Extremely well-realized main character benefits from having relatively diverse dialog options which help define his personality along the way, whether he ends up as a chain-smoking stoic or someone else depending on your choices. Supporting characters succeed at being memorable, with couple of exceptions, and help propel the game further with possible future twists and turns hinted towards by the game's system messages.In the end, this is a game bearing Telltale Games' characteristic hallmarks and flair - you know what to expect length-wise, characterization-wise and you're already crossing your fingers for another season. Make it happen.

As far as gameplay goes, it's pretty much just like Telltale's more recent games, but morally questionable choices dripping with consequences, QTEs, and excellent dialogue are far from bad. All in all, it's fantastic. I played it through a few times to see all the choices/get all the achievements, and it's really cool to see what Telltale did with the Fables universe.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												The Wolf Among Us is a Telltale Adventure game in the vein of The Walking Dead series. It takes place in the world of the Fables comics, where characters from myths and fairytales are alive and living in modern-day New York. Through the course of the game, you make choices through dialog trees and point-and-click adventure gameplay, which can cause (mildly) divergent paths throughout the plotline, making the game's experience your own. The story itself deals with a noir-esque mystery, where you take on the role of Sheriff Big B. Wolf, aiming to solve a murder.The game, taken as a whole, is very well crafted. Voice acting is top-notch, and there's some rather subtle lore and information spread throughout - it was wholly enjoyable and I highly recommend it. The one negative that I would say about the game is that there are a large number of action sequences which use QTE to resolve themselves, so if QTE are not your cup of tea, that may drag down on your opinion of the game. It's difficult to get into much greater detail without delving into the plot itself, which is the whole point with these games, so I'll leave it at that. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Telltale has successfully applied their 'The Walking Dead' formula & mechanics, this time capturing the essence of film noir and (hopefully) the Fables comic (which I haven't read). The Wolf Among Us takes more cues than ever from cinema, with ample establishing shots between acts, vignettes from interesting angles and simulated lens effects. These little details all help create depth and atmosphere and well, I just love that kinda stuff.The writing is fairly decent and the characters are likeable. Since it's a fairytale-inspired comic-inspired noir, it's difficult in fairness to call anything cliché or one-dimensional, though objectively I suppose much of it is. I prefer to call it heavily themed or stylised. Whatever, it works.Most of the interaction is superficial and the game is rather linear, but I didn't mind because the interaction served well to keep me engaged in the story while giving the impression of nonlinearity. However, a much enticing replay will quickly expose this illusion leaving you disappointed. Just play it once and live with your choices. Let it be.LIKES: -Amazing art direction, lighting & palette had me in screenshot frenzy.-Top notch voice acting for a game. Subtle, moody soundtrack adds a heap.-Plentiful badassitude.DISLIKES:-Predictable formula makes all the decisions about how people will judge you, rather than the logical path, or the role playing path. This heavily influenced my choices. However, see next point.-Telltale say the choices matter. This is a lie. They are merely noted upon.-The ending was a huge disappointment after some great mystery and drama along the way. It left me wanting a more compelling climax and plot twist.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												This game is astounding in it's presentation, storytelling and overall production. Telltale Games IMO has become the masters of adventure games and interactive storytelling. This is a high tech "choose your own adventure" story book. The story itself was gripping. The acting was very good. The cinematic feel to it was very engaging. I haven't taken in an adventure game so good since the Walking Dead series or even Grimm Fandango. Trust me, for the price you will get far more entertainment value than any movie in theaters. Plus no crying babies, overpriced popcorn and you can sip all the Scotch you want.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												This is a contender with The Walking Dead: Season 1 for Telltale's best game in my eyes. If one is taking art direction into consideration, this is easily the most beautiful game Telltale has ever released. The stylings are gorgeous, the mood pitch-perfect, and that intro sequence has me wanting a Season 2 for more of them alone.I wasn't the slightest bit familiar with the Fables universe going into this game, and it would be fair to say my expectations were set very low. That said: I was sold on it by the time Bigby lit his cigarette, the reverb of his lighter flick springboarding into a slick, fantastically atmospheric musical intro sequence.I experienced a lot of moments in this game like that. Be it the sound, art, writing, or the voice acting (let me shout out Bigby again here); this is an inspired piece of work from top to bottom. I finished episode 5 tonight and the afterglow is incredible.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Anyone else getting this awkward feeling Telltale Games has a really objectionable stance towards tangible gameplay? They continue with their steady decline away from it in the effort to focus on storytelling instead, as if the two are mutually exclusive somehow in their mind. Having said that, The Wolf Among Us manages to deliver a compelling story, if a bit blase for the fans of the detective genre, which manages to keep you engaged and its structure as a mystery seems to work really well with the now alredy tried-and-true episodic format. Extremely well-realized main character benefits from having relatively diverse dialog options which help define his personality along the way, whether he ends up as a chain-smoking stoic or someone else depending on your choices. Supporting characters succeed at being memorable, with couple of exceptions, and help propel the game further with possible future twists and turns hinted towards by the game's system messages.In the end, this is a game bearing Telltale Games' characteristic hallmarks and flair - you know what to expect length-wise, characterization-wise and you're already crossing your fingers for another season. Make it happen.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												The Wolf Among Us is a game I never really expected much from, but was completely blown away. I will even admittedly say that I may have even enjoyed this series more than TellTale's famous The Walking Dead series.--Final thoughts at the bottom--GameplayThe game play is reminiscent to TellTales other adventure games. You progress through the story by investigating areas to find useful information or a way of proceding to the next area. Their is no complex puzzles or anything to get you stuck as the game is heavily story related so it tries to keep you progressing. Most of the gameplay is about carefully choosing your response to conversations or story event where you must choose between doing X or doing Y. Quicktime events fill in alot of the action parts and add to the intensity.GraphicsThe cell shaded art style fits perfectly into this world they have created. The characters are well drawn and animated, some feel very recognizable. The facial movements and body movements look good, however some people still seem to walk like they have a stick up their butt(This is an issue I have with all TellTale games). The world they have created sets the perfect setting for how the story takes place. The amount of detail they went into on some of the level design is very well done, even in places you arent around for very long. Its nice to see them still put the detail in to make this feel like a live breathing world.AudioThe sound is done very well in The Wolf Among Us. The background noise and ambience was well done. The music is superb for the style they are going for in this game. The theme song kinda reminds me of Farcry 3: Blood Dragon music. The ingame music was very good at setting the mood for the events happening as well as for the areas you were exploring.The voice over work is phenomenal and is what brings this story to life. The voices chosen for each character fit their rolls perfectly. Not once did I hear any voice that I thought to myself "that doesn't fit". The emotions are portrayed very well through their voices and sucks the player into the story. Top notch voice acting all around.StoryThe story is where this game really shines. I must admit I was never really interested in this game, nor did I really here to much about it, other than "Its good". So I went in knowing nothing about the plot or anything. Wow was I blown away by what I experienced.It takes place in a place known as "Fabletown" which is a small community of fables built on the outskirts of a real world city(I believe its New York). This community is build up of Fables who have left "The woodlands" and have moved into city to live in a real society. However when murders start happening, fabletown turns to terror. You, Bigby Wolf, AKA the big bad wolf, being the sheriff must hunt down and get to the bottom of whoever is behind it. One way or Another. This is The Wolf Among Us's biggest feature. The choices. Every choice you make in this game effects the story severely, even more than TellTales other games. In the walking dead when you madea choice it always felt like no matter what you did it would still end up being the same result, however the wolf among us does the opposite. Every choice effects how people in fabletown view you, which in turn effects trust, reliability, story arc changes and much more. You begin to really care about the characters. You begin to take more time with decisions, knowing that what you do could make characters love or hate you and this could effect how useful they are to you down the line. The story progresses very fluently and keeps you wanting to know more. Their are loads of plot twists that will keep your mind bumbling for more answers. Just when you think you got it figured out, *BAM!!* plot twist. my only complaint about the story was that it was rather short, I played through all 5 episodes in less than 8hrs.Final thoughtsAfter going into this game knowing nothing about it other than "its good", I must say I was blown away by the world they created, and The story had me hooked and thinking about it even when I wasnt playing. The way this game makes you care for its characters is incredible and the obsolutely phenomenal voice over work brings them to life with a voice. The animation and level design is gorgeously done in TellTale's signature cell shaded art and everything plays very smooth with a smooth looking framerate, which is I know alot of problem had with the first season of the walking dead. If you are looking for a game with a unique world and setting, with an amazing story. Then you will love the Wolf Among Us. If you are on the fence about this game, its definetly worth the buy. For a game I wasnt expecting much out of, I must say I think this may be my favourite game created by TellTale(Yes even better than the walking dead).

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												I took the whole day to finish this game because I found it so hard to put down. There isn't much confusion as to what pick-up item bribes who like you'd witness in Sam & Max. In fact, I can only remember using a key for one of Ichabod's doors. Maybe the developers, for this particular game, believed those mechanics would ♥♥♥♥ with the pacing. Spoilers from here on out... what a thought-provoking game, especially after I looked up the alternate endings, you'd find it impossible to please everyone in the "trial" (I use quotes here because I, along with apparently just 12% of the players, decided to kill the Crooked Man under the impression that only death could free the town from a person who can manipulate any situation). I was looking forward to seeing whether or not the Crooked Man, our final antagonist, had some formiddable fable transformation; but I suppose I'm fine with the Bloody Mary battle. Maybe it serves the narrative more that the Crooked Man is just a human fable, but really more of a statement[en.wikipedia.org] on the nature of keeping someone's interests while holding them in debt (manipulation). This game was unusually cerebral and consulted multiple themes at once. I want the review to be brief, but the trial made for a good microcosm on the role of the government (in other words, a one-size-fits-all will always be met with opposition). It was pretty sad to see Mr. Toad and his son deported to the farm; there was a strong sense of "everything is ♥♥♥♥ed beyond reason and there's nothing you can do to make it right" which underlined every one of my decisions. I can already tell I'm going to think on this ending for awhile. Also, it's important to note an issue at the end of episode five which forced me into inescapable prompts of choice bubbles reading "This choice is blank!" Resetting the game seemed to fix this. Good product overall. As a consequence of eating my ice cream in one bite, I hope a need to see fable monsters beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of eachother didn't override any appreciation of the story.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												Better than Walking Dead Season 2 and better than its own source material. The Wolf Among Us takes the universe of the Fables comics -- where characters from myth, legend and fairytale hide among us in New York City -- and gives it an extra noir spin by setting it in the grimy red-light districts of the city's 1980s.Like Telltale's other recent episodic adventures, it's less about winning the game than about who you are and what the world looks like when your story is done. How far will Sheriff Bigby Wolf go to protect the people of Fabletown when the system fails everyone around him?

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												After some major trouble in the homelands of the fairytale characters they flee to the normal (mundy) world of New York City. Here they find out that things are hard and hardly end 'happily ever after'. This is the background of a gritty and dark Telltale adventure where your choices make the story and helped with some quick-time events make this an action adventure too.The main character is Bigby Wolf, the big bad wolf from the fairytales who is now the sheriff of 'Fabletown' and has to deal with the growing discontent of the fairytale creatures who find it hard to live as 'normal'  people. No one trusts him and everybody is scared of this beast with his bloody history. And then the unrest really starts when a murder is committed. As the story unfolds you discover that this runs way deeper and will influence the very excistence of Fabletown and its inhabitants.I really enjoyed this story, although I sometimes got frustrated by the quick-time events and the short time-period you are given to make your choices. But the story was so gripping that I finished chapters 3 to 5 in one go.I highly recommend this game to everyone who like story driven games and I guarentee everyone who has read their fair share of fairytales you'll have fun recognising every character and the way they are portrayed in this modern-day fairytale.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												The "Wolf Among Us" is a very well made and engaging narrative adventure. Unlike the other works from Telltale Games, this game doesn't take inspiration from a popular movie or game franchise, instead it crafts a very original setting (inspired by a comic) where classic "fables" left their lands to move into New York City, where they have to hide their true nature.The game follows "Bigby", the Big Bad Wolf from the "Little Red Riding Hood" tale.Bigby is the sheriff of "Fabletown" and he'll have to collaborate with other fables to uncover the macabre mysteries of fabletown's underworld.The Wolf Among Us is a very intriguing thriller which explores a darker side of the classic tales we heard as kids and dips everything in an insanely well designed neo-noire atmosphere, mixing the classic detective movies from the 1950s with a stylish 1980s appearance and music.Very highly recommended, specially because of it's undeniable originality.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												Another TellTale masterpiece in interactive narrative with great characters. Pros: - Story. A deadly mystery that delves deeply in Fables (fairy tale) lore and packs a substantial amounts of twists - Characters! Bigby, Snow, Crane or Georgie, each is finely crafted with stellar voice acting - voice acting!!  - soundtrack. very atmospheric - perfect TellTale style choices - easy on your machine, still looks good and is immersive - sets are designed with love and care - it gets pretty brutal - I love the openingCons: - not a game per se. more of an interactive TV series - some might be turned off by the more graphic and explicit nature of The Wolf Among Us. tread with care if sexual or overly violent content offends or disgusts you - absolutely uninspired 'achievements' ... rather wish they skip that.Verdict:A must have for fans of the Fable comics, and surely a great addition to anyone's library.The Wolf Among Us delivers a mature crime drama with supernatural elements, sprinkled with some good old fashioned ultra violence. This is served with memorable characters, performances and development.Better than TV

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Visually this series has been absolutely gorgeous from the get-go.  Despite the fact that certain areas are supposed to be decrepit and run-down they are colorful and detailed.  The characters are expressive and unique.  The "cinematography" if you can call it that is top-notch.  It's easy to see everything you need to when exploring and it follows the action well in dramatic/fight scenes.The music is relatively subdued and low key but it compliments the game well enough.  The visuals with the 80s synth sound call to mind things like Drive/Hotline Miami which I'm not sure if that was intentional.The controls for the series have mostly been spot on.  I played with a 360 controller and I may have stumbled a bit or two on a QTE but it was nothing crippling.  One issue with the game is that since you are using fixed-camera angles if you are holding say "up" and move into a new room, "up" may become "left" and the game doesn't seem to interpret the change properly.  It's a minor gripe though and not game-breaking.The gameplay isn't much to write home about to be honest.  You're either interacting with everything on screen until you've run out of options, doing a QTE sequence or choosing from multiple conversation options.  I think the real winner here is that rather than burdening the series with obtuse moon-logic puzzles, Telltale elected to keep the game elements light in favor of the story.  That's not to say you don't interact with or shape the story.  Be warned you are looking at about 10 hours of gameplay here.  For some that may be a drawback, but for me it was the draw.  Those 10 hours have no filler or wasted content.The story in TWAU is phenomenal and is the real draw to the game.  Granted it is based on the existing Fables graphic novel series but from what I understand a lot of the plot for the game if not all of it was created from scratch.  The writing and voice acting are top notch here, and Telltale fans will notice some familiar voices from previous games.  Aside from Bigby most of the other characters are multi-faceted and compelling.  People who immediately seem innocuous and friendly may have dark secrets, people who are at first glance are two bit thugs may actually have some humanity in them.  All of your interactions with the Fables both good and bad come back to you, so be careful what you choose.All around, I can't recommend this game enough.  It's clear that Telltale learned a lot from The Walking Dead and their previous games and the are really only getting better at what they do.  Yes the game is short and is largely more focused on narrative than gameplay, but if you're okay with that there's a lot to love here.  Absolutely buy this game.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I strongly recommend this awesome game... but wait for it. Summer 2014.Everything's damn perfect in this adventure game. The mood, the writing, the art direction, the sound, the setting... Telltale at its best, by far.YET... I do not recommend the small episodes scattered around the year. The game's experience should get much much better if you can actually play them all in a row. The first episode finishes on a big bad old cliffhanger... and those really have a meaning when you only have to wait the follow up for about a week or so. Not six month.You should also understand this game is heavily based on QTE. If it's not for you, it's not for you.I can't comment on the story though. Everything is about the story in this game, and it is very easy to spoil it. All I can say is it's top notch.Wait until summer 2014, then buy this game as hard as you can!

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												Best Stress Reliever game, totally maimed Grendel and enjoyed it.Postives-Amazing Voice Acting-Unique Visuals-Unique and traditional Telltale games gameplay-Amazing characters, unforgetable, most likeable and some not so much-Character Progression-Twists and Cliffhangers thoughout the GameNegatives-The waiting time for each episode, its because it has cliffhangers at the end of each episode-May experience some bugs (minor ones though)Rating: MUST BUY!Final Verdict: 10/10Overall, unless you are extremely unpatient, I suggest you wait until all the episodes are release (which by this point they probably are). If you are patient though, then grab this game right now, it is worth every penny. EDIT:I gave it a 10 cause even now after I finish the game I still am waiting for a DLC or a sequel, c'mon. Even thought it might take 2016 for the sequel to come out due to the Tales for Borderlands game they are making and the Game Of Thrones game. Unlike the Walking Dead Season 2 which I saw the ending as a bit of a let-down and even after finishing that TellTale Game, I still want this game to have a sequel.

												After some major trouble in the homelands of the fairytale characters they flee to the normal (mundy) world of New York City. Here they find out that things are hard and hardly end 'happily ever after'. This is the background of a gritty and dark Telltale adventure where your choices make the story and helped with some quick-time events make this an action adventure too.The main character is Bigby Wolf, the big bad wolf from the fairytales who is now the sheriff of 'Fabletown' and has to deal with the growing discontent of the fairytale creatures who find it hard to live as 'normal'  people. No one trusts him and everybody is scared of this beast with his bloody history. And then the unrest really starts when a murder is committed. As the story unfolds you discover that this runs way deeper and will influence the very excistence of Fabletown and its inhabitants.I really enjoyed this story, although I sometimes got frustrated by the quick-time events and the short time-period you are given to make your choices. But the story was so gripping that I finished chapters 3 to 5 in one go.I highly recommend this game to everyone who like story driven games and I guarentee everyone who has read their fair share of fairytales you'll have fun recognising every character and the way they are portrayed in this modern-day fairytale.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												The "Wolf Among Us" is a very well made and engaging narrative adventure. Unlike the other works from Telltale Games, this game doesn't take inspiration from a popular movie or game franchise, instead it crafts a very original setting (inspired by a comic) where classic "fables" left their lands to move into New York City, where they have to hide their true nature.The game follows "Bigby", the Big Bad Wolf from the "Little Red Riding Hood" tale.Bigby is the sheriff of "Fabletown" and he'll have to collaborate with other fables to uncover the macabre mysteries of fabletown's underworld.The Wolf Among Us is a very intriguing thriller which explores a darker side of the classic tales we heard as kids and dips everything in an insanely well designed neo-noire atmosphere, mixing the classic detective movies from the 1950s with a stylish 1980s appearance and music.Very highly recommended, specially because of it's undeniable originality.

												This is a very slick title, based on same engine as The Walking Dead. Light on puzzles and inventory, linear but will remember dialogue decisions to offer slightly different progression. It is a beautiful and thrilling title to play.What is isn't however is a traditional adventure game. number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												Some of my first and most vital PC gaming experiences, growing up, involved the classic point-and-click adventure. I'll always have a soft spot in my heart for those kind of games. Once again, Telltale games has revitalized the entire genre with The Wolf Among Us.  I purposefully kept a blind ear and eye to every single bit of information/reviews/videos when it came to this game and what it was about, until the moment I could play it for myself. I was more than pleasantly surprised to discover it was based on the comics I have been reading and enjoying for the past few months--The Fables series. And I have to say, it really does the comic book series justice, both in style and character.  But don't worry, even if you've never read the series you can easily delve deeply into the world this game presents. Who doesn't like a good murder mystery? It's even better when you get to take the role of detective (or in this case, Sheriff), sniffing out clues and interrogating suspects, piecing together evidence bit by bit. In this case, you are none other than the Big Bad Wolf, who has been assigned to bring law and order to Fabletown: a magical and rather grisly place tucked away in New York, where many creatures of legend and fairytale characters have been exiled to live. As you can expect, not everybody plays nicely with each other, and pretty soon things end up bloody.  I love how the game really gives you complete control over your character's personality and detective skills, though it could be frustrating at times when you come to realize something major yourself...only to wait and guide your character to eventually come to the same conclusion.Most point-and-click adventures let you explore freely and take your time, it's all rather leisurely. And although there is plenty of room to explore around Fabletown, taking your time really isn't an option. At all. To me, though, this only adds to the tension and excitement you feel as the story unfolds. The game is highly cinematic in nature, so that if you step away or stop paying attention for one moment....you could miss a critical clue, lose your sway in a conversation, or worse. You must constantly be on your toes and ready to make decisions that help shape the way your character is perceived and solve the case. Not only that, it makes the game nearly impossible to want to stop playing, and that's a very good thing. I found myself glued to the seat and highly focused for each and every episode of this. The game reminds me of an old noir crime movie, with plenty of seedy characters, red herrings, blood, sex, brutal fistfights and relentless twists and turns. It's highly intellectual and really forces you to think for yourself, but I guarantee you will always be second-guessing yourself throughout, playing back old conversations and situations to make sure you did the right thing.  After all, the game is filled with varying choices, and it's these nuances that not only add to the first time experience of playing--but also offer replay value. I won't spoil the end, of course, but I will say only this: If you played the game as intensely as I did, you won't be able to stop thinking about it for at least a few days. And the best kinds of games are the ones that haunt you and stay with you like that, in my opinion.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Telltale hits it out of the park once again, with another excellent story-telling experience. The Wolf Among Us is one of Telltale's latest and greatest point-and-click story-driven adventures, but it is based off of the popular comic series Fables. Due to this, you'd think Telltale would have to play it safe so it wouldn't disrupt any of the canon of the comics. At the end of the first episode, though, you'll see that Telltale isn't pulling any punches. The first thing you'll notice about the game are its aesthetics. TWOU is using a color pallette Telltale hasn't used before, and it takes advantage of the Telltale engine and a neon color scheme. This game has a lot of shadows, which really fit the already engrossing atmosphere. Here I'm gonna give a review of each episode released so far, then once Cry Wolf is released, I'll give my thoughts on that and give a final review of this game.---Episode 1: FaithThis episode helps setup the main narrative of the entire series, and makes it so you really don't need to know much about Fables to understand the plot. Right away you're thrust into the role of Bigby Wolf and given some choices on how to react to an emergency that's happening in the main setting of the game, Fabletown. So, during these first 10 minutes, you have multiple choices and a great action sequence that introduces you to 4 very important characters. As this episode progresses you learn more about Fabletown and its residents, and start wondering about all the little secrets that may lie unknown in this little town. The episodes length is roughly 2 hours, but is very replayable for the Book of Fables entries and the other choices you can make. The choices made in this episode drastically impact the rest of the story, so you're going to need to choose very wisely. Overall, this episode is a 9/10---Episode 2: Smoke and MirrorsThis is the episode we waited for for over 4 months, and I'd like to say it was worth the wait. This episode explains the cliffhanger ending from the first episode (WHICH TOOK 4 MONTHS TO RESOLVE) and reveals some more insight into the character of Bigby Wolf and of his other friends. From the very beginning you're able to make difficult choices on how to handle bad situations, which are reflective on your playstyle, and what type of mental state you think Bigby is in. What makes up for the tragic wait for this episode is the devastating conclusion and realization at the very end of the episode, leaving you on a cliffhanger to start episode 3 with. 9/10---Episode 3: A Crooked MileThe best episode by far. Everything in this episode is expertly made, from the beginning, to the choices, to the end. This is one of the longest episodes by far, but I can't really go into detail without spoiling it. Truly the pinnacle of Telltale's story telling, 10/10---Episode 4: In Sheep's ClothingA lackluster episode when it comes to length and decisions, but a good one nonetheless. This episode of TWOU is an example of Telltale's episode 4 curse, where they can't seem to deliver with their penultimate episodes. This episode is probably the shortest one out of the bunch, but is thoroughly enjoyable. The cliffhanger will have you drooling and counting down the days until Episode 5's release. 7/10

content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												From the makers of The Walking Dead game series comes a unique murder mystery series about a world of famous fable characters forced to don human appearances in order to live among the human world.  You play as Bigby Wolf, A.K.A, the Big Bad Wolf, tasked with the safety of Fabletown where he and his fellow fables reside.  Suddenly, after several years, a fable is murdered and their decapitated head is left outside Bigby's apartment building to find.  Now there's an ever growing number of suspects to the murder, and it's up to Bigby to decide which of his fellow fables is the killer.If you've played The Walking Dead, this title will be very familiar to you.  Branching story, difficult descisions, outstanding writing, QTE action sequences, it's all there.  You can pretty much refer back to my Walking Dead reccomendation for how the mechanics go here, but there's absolutely nothing wrong with that, as the star of the show is the story and how you decide what to do in it, and boy is it a gripping one indeed.  Just like before, it's episodic, so one $25 purchase will be good for all 5 episodes to come!  If you're a lover of fantastic video game story, you owe it to yourself to pick this one up!  Actually, just do it, ya ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												The Wolf Among Us is inspired by the Fable comics. Let's speak clearly: it's a great hommage to this comics series, both respectful and capable of adding to the original. The game is an adventure game that works as a serial, with strong characters and a solid thriller story. The game's not about difficult enigmas our strange environment but it's more about trying to tell a story in an unprecedented format (except for The Walking Dead game). And it does a great job at it. Really, being the main character, choosing your answers, your way around and chasing who you think is the suspect has a real impact on the way you enjoy the story. Once again, a masterpiece for Telltame Games.Compared to The Walking DeadThough very similar to The Walking Dead (which I enjoyed), this video games series seems better to me. Despite its link to childhood themes (fairy tales coming to life), it eems more mature and works around topics like : taking responsability for your action or passion versus reason. It sure isn't as much of an emotional roller coaster as TWD. More of a philosophical tale. Besides, this one definetely has more interactivity than TWD

												Прекрасная история, которая вкупе с отличными персонажами и атмосферой развратного города на выходе даёт потрясающией результат. В Фейблтауне у каждого есть свои скелеты в шкафу, все что-то скрывают, замалчивают, но Большого и Страшного Серого Волка это не останавливает. Он упрямо движётся к своей цели, несмотря ни на что. Его не останавливают даже заряды дроби в упор. От эпизода к эпизоду напряжение всё нарастает, становится всё запутаннее и интереснее, но в конце концов весь этот клубок тайн и загадок раскрывается нам в конце, который, к слову сказать, всё же кажется немного слитым, ибо градус напряжения в нём ощутимо меньше чем раньше. number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												Dear player: you are dumb. You're such a socially inept nerd, you probably can't even interpret facial expressions or voice pitching. That's why we will inform you with those neat "XYZ will remember that" boxes. Also we really love to delude you into buying the thought that "every decision can have enormous consequences", even though in the 9 hours you will play this game, there are only like 3 occasions were this statement would really be the case. No matter what you do, the plot line will always head in the same direction, at the same speed. There's no branching path or shortcut at all. So even if you connect the clues the game gives you, you may wait a very long time till your ingame character does so. The choices you can make are once again very limited.So much for rambling about the bad points. Now onto the good stuff, which imho fortunately outweighs everything mentioned previously.The game is based on the DC Comic Series "Fables". Once you are into the game you immediately got that gritty noir vibe going. It's atmospheric, stylish and quite unique in the gaming sector. The cell-shading graphics fit that base very well. From what I can tell the voice acting also is very professional and completely flawless. Even though the story tends to be stereotypical at times, the characters are believable in their own motivations and actions. There's no black and white run-of-the-mill evil villain to find here. It's almost like the story arc - just like the artstyle, the music and voice acting - is once more another plattform for the twisted and crazy, but often still very likeable characters to shine through.I played through the complete game in about 9 hours and the standard price would be 22,99€ in Europe (Tier 1). That is a lot of value for your money, considering that this game feels more like watching an entire season of an interactive series then anything else.Here you go. The 'Call of Duty' of adventure games. Just like Activision took the essence of action games and multiplied it by 10 for the sake of entertainment, while leaving out the more interesting aspects of gameplay, Telltale do the same thing in their own genre. It's extremely dialogue-heavy and entertaining, but if you're looking for interesting gameplay.. go look somewhere else.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												This game is supposed to be a prequel to a comic book series called Fables. It is about all sorts of fairy tale characters we know (e.g. Red Riding Hood, Beauty and Beast) who live among us as they were forced to leave their home. In Fabletown (which is part of New York) they try to blend in with the humans (who they call "mundies") and for those not having human form it proves to be difficult: an enchantment called "glamour" is a must to change forms, otherwise they are sent to "The Farm" which is not exactly a place any Fable wants to be.The game takes place in the '80s and the player assumes the control of the Wolf from Red Riding Hood. Big Wolf - or Bigby - acts as the Sheriff of Fabletown and is set out to solve a crime that ended in the death of one of the Fables. He is aided by Snow White and other fairy tale / folklore characters we may or may not recognise.Now, if you have already played a Telltale adventure game Wolf Among Us will be familiar to you:--- there are a relatively few places where objects can be picked up or interacted with (we have the option to investigate our surroundings while the rest of the game gives us a mainly film-like experience with lots of cutscenes and dialogues)--- your inventory does not really get full of items and if an item can be used with another one in the environment the game tells you that --- there are lots of characters to speak with and during conversations you have a limited time to pick an answer - these affect the relationship you have with these people and a choice can often have dire consequences--- due to the availability of choices a 2nd or even a 3rd walkthrough can easily yield you new results (the changes can even affect the end game)--- during action sequences quick-time-events are common but the pop-up buttons are easy to hit - this is not a difficult game (the main idea here is the immersion)Wolf Among Us sports an interesting story and it entertains you from start to finish while you try to find the killer of Fabletown. Since prior to this I played the Walking Dead series I can make a comparison between the two: Wolf has more action sequences and while there's drama it certainly is less emotional. Oh, and make no mistake: just because it is about fairy tale characters gore and violence (along with cursing) is common.For fans of Telltale adventure games this is a recommended title - for newcomers it's also worth checking.

												I made a mistake by playing the first chapter way back when it first released because you have to remember all the details, at least it helps. As of now I have gone through all 5 episodes 3 or 4 times each so it does really pay off to remember the small details.       You are Sheriff Bigby Wolf, in our world, New York. The fables try to keep regular citizens(Mundies) out by using glamours to appear normal. When a few heads start to roll in Fabletown it's up to Bigby to solve this dangerous mystery that will keep twisting. As for the gameplay, the mechanics are typical for Tellatale. They are QTE prompts but you are the choreographer of the fight scenes which is why I love The Wolf Among Us, as well as its well designed consequence system. If you have read Fables by DC Vertigo you would understand more but you still have a great story either way.Personal Score(Average for all episodes): 9.6Really impressive story telling on Telltale's part; hopefully we can see another season!!!!!!!

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												It's hard to talk about The Wolf Among Us without comparing it to its older brother The Walking Dead as they practically share the same game style. Tell Tale did a great revamp with the point and click adventure genre and what truly shines for their newer instalments are the players dialogue and action inputs that affect that story as you progress.Playing as Fable sheriff Bigby Wolf (The big bad wolf) you have a bad reputation for having a temper and violent tendencies. The games theme is based around judgement of character and lets you choose to whether live up to your tenacity or redeem yourself in the folks that you serve and protect.Always thinking about your actions and seeing your consequences unfold blurs the lines of good and bad and that's what makes TWAU really stand out. Will you assert your authority? Show remorse? Keep your cool? or unleash who you really are?Solve the case, help clean up Fable town. And show your true side.... Your bite maybe worse than your bark.

												If you liked The Walking Dead you will also like this. It's a bit more action-oriented. I wouldn't call it "noir" (or at least not too much) or "mature";  it's basically fairytale characters, gritty & edgy version in a crapsack modern-ish world. But the execution works really well in my opinion.You play as the big bad wolf (hence the Bigby name), there's snow white, there's the dwarves, there's beauty & the beast, etc. it's  a bit of an adult mix of the stories of your childhood, wrapped up in a thriller/murder/investigation package.It certainly feels better paced and more interactive than The Walking Dead to me but both have different aims & goals.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												I went into The Wolf Among Us blissfully ignorant. All I knew was that it was in a smilar vein to the excellent The Walking Dead games and had the same developers. I was rather delighted by an absolutely fantastic surprise of a game. An ultra-violent film noir mixed with a fantasy world. The story sounds odd on paper but is very smart and oozes style. Basically, it's about the classic characters of fairy tales (Snow White, The Big Bad Wolf, Three Little Pigs, Beauty and the Beast, etc) having to leave their magical homeworld to escape destruction and they settle in Manhattan, in an area called Fable Town. Use of a drug called "Glamour" conceals their non-human form (if they are non human, characters such as Snow White and Beauty don't have to) and if they cannot afford Glamour, they are sent to a rural enclave, some would say prison, known as The Farm. The well off and high-ups live in an apartment complex called The Woodlands, whilst the under-classes and wretches of society live in the impoverished fringes. It's a world much like our own, far removed from any magical connotations. Don't think of the themes as being child friendly too. It's a very mature game with mature themes, with violence to boot. Think of it as the characters of Disney in the world of a film noir murder mystery. Fast forward to the modern day. You play as Sheriff Bigby Wolf, aka The Big Bad Wolf, who is tasked with keeping law and order in Fabletown. He's a typical hard talking, hard living, gritty detective of classic film. A serial killler, a completely new thing for Fabletown, is on the loose and you have to stop him. During this investigation many questions are raised on class boundaries, injustice and the hardship faced by citizens of Fabletown. Bigby's moral compass is tested and sometimes he fails to keep the wolf inside him from coming out, quite literally. It's enthralling. The game plays very similarly to The Walking Dead. It's a point and click adventure focused on player choice and story. I think it rises above Walking Dead in that the story is more compelling, the characters more interesting and overall the artistic license gives the writers more room to maneuver and craft a better story. The art direction is absolutely fantastic too. The game looks lovely, with animations being a much improved area. The soundtrack is brilliant, very subtle but never fails to convey a particular mood or sense of place. The first episode was about 2 and a half hours long and I enjoyed every minute of it. One of the best story based games I've had the privilege of playing and if the rest of the episodes live up to this then it'll be one of the best games I've ever played. Heartily recommended. Near perfect in what it sets out to achieve.

												Episode 1 or “Faith” is an excellent first 2 hour or so long chapter in The Wolf Among Us story. The presentation is in every way fantastic, with the one down side being the somewhat jarring frame problems during transitions, these are largely neglectable and they managed to make this world of fables come alive. If you are looking for a game that features many puzzles and gives you plenty of room to uncover its secrets, you are unlikely to find it here. Gameplay is greatly paced during the fight scenes, but not so much when you are given free roam. If you are however looking for a great universe with great story, characters and dialogue.. well, you need not look further.With episode 1, The Wolf Among Us is looking like it will be a fantastic episodic experience to play through.
