It isn't even really that bad either considering the entire game.Telltale MAKE SEASON 2! 10/10

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												Another example of very good Telltale story-telling games, this game is overall very great, very colorful, nice graphics, if you played The Walking Dead Telltale games you most likely would like this one too. You play as a guy named "Bigby Wolf", this game is based on comics about him, he is that "Big Bad Wolf from Little Red Riding Hood", all the characters are form different stories, books, etc, they live in our world, but hiding that they're "Fables", is how they call them selves (all characters that come from these stories, books, etc), the one's that don't look like humans use "glamours" to look like them, but it's not a cheap thing, and the one's who can't afford it live in "The Farm" a little place separated place from human living zones. Bigby is a sheriff who solves crimes like a detective, finds the responsibles, facts, to help other Fables, etc, because of his past(in the tale "Little Red Riding Hood") some Fables are afraid or don't respect him, but he is a good guy, who cares about his friends and about others, but nervous and sometimes little aggressive. The game is basically a detective story with magic and magic/story/fairy creatures involved, the "Fables". There is a crime happening in "Fabletown" and you need to figure out all information, depending on your choices happens different things, and other characters have different relation with you.Rating by Episodes:1st  Amazing2nd Amazing3rd Amazing4th Good5th RegularOverall very enjoyable game, I liked it a lot, not more than The Walking Dead, but is awesome and not grayish, you will like it if you like storytelling games with amazing stories.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Overall, a nice interactive adventure from Telltale. The game is based off the Fables graphic novels, which is an amazing concept. I love the game's style, humor, plot, characters, and I would also say writing if it had been more thought-out.It's a game entirely devoid of common sense at times: "Why would you do that, Bigby? What's wrong with you? Why you can't you ___ or ___!". Well, why? Because I was almost murdered an abundant amount of times, because these people are suspected of murder, because I'm just trying to get information, and etc. And, the dialogue is based off these outlandish notions that have no sense to it.It's not a small issue, but extremely prevelant, so much so that I find myself stuck with these or similar thoughts almost every single scene in the game. There's a whole lot of whining, going circles and circles, in a story that's otherwise extremely interesting. Still, it's a very nice adventure I'm glad I took.Edit done to cut down on unneccessary length.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												Story based game with some action scenes. Your dialogue choices in game will determine the direction of the story and events that occur throughout your progression. You are Sheriff Bigby Wolf (Big Bad Wolf), the sheriff of Fabletown, a group of fairy tale characters that are living in New York disguised by magic. You are investigating a crime when you uncover much bigger things going on in FabletownI highly recommend this game, especially now that all the chapters are out. I purchased it when only the first chapter of the game was out. I did not have to pay anything else other than the initial purchase price to get access to the additional chapters (there are 5 in total). The animation is good and the gameplay fun. The writing for the story is excellent and can really draw the player in. I would definitely give this game a try, especially if you can pick it up on sale for a good price! I have no qualms in saying, though, that, even if you pay full price, this game is worth every single penny you'll spend. TellTale really hit the nail on the head with this one.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												By now the Telltale games shouldn't be much of a surprise in terms of gameplay. It's an interactive story. So the real question is what does TWAU have to offer you?I liked The Walking Dead series, so I decided to jump on this. I'm glad I did.This is a WEIRD world set in 80s NYC and somehow it works. It looks like the 80s in that the clothes, cars, neon setting, etc. all give it a realistic feel. Now populate that world with living, breathing fairy tale creatures like Beauty and the Beast, Snow White and the Magic Mirror  interwoven in a murder mystery and you have the makings of something unique. You're Bigsby Wolf - The Big Bad Wolf - and it's your job as Sheriff to investigate this murder.Along the way, you'll find a dark tale that shows that even fairy tales don't have happy endings - murder, slavery, depression, suicide and prostitution - all come into play. It's a great story made greater by a very interesting setting. As always, these "games" are more interactive stories and less game. The voice acting is well done and the plot interesting. The typical Telltale art style works well in this setting.Overall, this is one of the best Telltale-type games and I wholeheartedly recommend it for fans of the material or game style.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												It's not really the murder mystery that makes me keep playing The Wolf Among Us. It's the meta-narrative that let's this game stand on it's own besides all the similarities with Telltales award winning The Walking Dead series. Bigby is not only a stereotypical noir detective, he's also a metaphor for the stereotypical gamer. The often needless violence itself becomes a topic of the story and there's this one question Bigby and the player need to ask themselves: Do you enjoy it?

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Once upon a time, in a land far away... actually, in modern times and in the middle of New York City, a community of fairytale-characters is living a life in secrecy. From Snow White to Beauty and The Beast, you know the tales. Being supernatural beings, they resort to a form of magical enchantment called "glamour" to appear human. To break the spell and show one's true self is strictly forbidden and would pose a threat to the entire community. The Fables, which is the name the residents have chosen for themselves, are kept in line by their own communal government, and there to enforce its will is the sheriff, Bigby Wolf aka The Big Bad Wolf - The protagonist of The Wolf Among Us and your character. Trouble is brewing in Fabletown, and Bigby is out to investigate.Gameplay-wise, this is your typical Telltales game. If you played The Walking Dead, you know what to expect from The Wolf Among Us, which uses the same mechanics (quasi-quicktime events with button-mashing, mouse-controls and a lot of dialogue).Of course this also includes the typical Telltales-style of graphics, utilising a hefty amount of cell-shading to give it that cartoony/comic look. This is an adventure-game more than anything else and, as usual, the player's choices are heavily advertised to cause a great impact on the game's later story. All dialogues have a multitude of possible answers for you to choose (including silence) and characters you talk to will remember how you have treated them in the past.The Wolf Among Us is an interactive story, and you choose the details.Before I blindly recommend this game to everyone, I should mention that it is not yet complete. In Telltales-fashion, TWAU is released episodically, with a delay of at least a month between new installments. You do get all of them for free after purchasing the game, but keep in mind that as of now, only the first episode is out, with the second one coming out in early February.Apart from this minor inconvenience, TWAU is well worth a look. The story so far is very interesting, has enough twists and shock-moments to keep you interested and really makes you wish for the next episode. Being based on the Fables-comics by Vertigo, the game has a very unique setting that should offer a fresh experience to all those who did not even know about the franchise (including myself). If you enjoyed how The Walking Dead played out, give this one a shot.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												I'm conflicted about The Wolf Among Us. I did enjoy the game and its story, but I feel like the pros and cons evened outPros:- I loved Bigby. I thought he was an excellent protagonist. One of my big gripes with games is when the main character isn't likeable. Bigby is a misunderstood bad guy turned good, and I think it worked well. The choices in the game also let you tailor Bigby to the kind of sheriff you want him to be.- It's a classic Telltale game. Episodic, story rich, and has choices you can make in the game.- The end of every episode left me wanting more. Luckily I bought the game after all the episodes came out.- Even though the game's idea isn't an original one, I still loved it. Fabled characters trying to adapt to the real world.- Wonderful voiceoversCons:- Even though I fell in love with Bigby, I disliked pretty much every other character except Toad and his son. I don't know if that is Telltale's fault or the comics, but I literally didn't care about most of the cast of characters.- The story kind of fell apart toward the end. It just got weird, and I felt it went downhill once Bloody Mary and the Crooked Man started playing a role. Also, Bloody Mary is probably one of the worst enemies I've ever witnessed in a game.- The illusion of choice: your choices in the game don't affect the story at all. The game hardly adapts at all to the choices you make.I say buy this game, but don't have high expectations.Also, there are no jump scares.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2013
												Okay, so it's the new episodic quest game from TellTale Games, the guys behind Sam&Max and The Walking Dead, among with Back to the Future, Jurassic Park and more. That's why the question "Well, how's the game?" sounds absolutely dumb. The first episode is great, full of investigations, dialogues and combat (remember, that we play as Sheriff, infamous known as Big Bad Wolf). Telltale also made another step to non-linear plot, because now even events within one episode can turn it one way or another - like with "new" feature of timing (there are 2 places where you have to be urgently, and you have decide where will you go). Now it's not "Save one or another, and he'll die 5 minutes after" dillema from TWD - your choices really matters... Or the illusion is way stronger - it's hard to tell about that now, after just one episode.After all... If you like interesting plot with many twists, hard choices and good dialogues with great characters (some of them were taken from DC Comics) with a sweet taste of violence (there are many really violent fights, and some of them are avoidable) - come and get it. Geniuses from Telltale deserved it.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												The Wolf Among Us is an episodic game adaption to the comic series Fables. The game takes place in a fictional New York City borough of Fabletown, where various mythical characters live. The game starts with a murder case that Bigby (Big Bad Wolf) and Snow White must solve before the killer strikes again. Their investigation leads to a dark underworld more extensive than they ever expected and the deeper they go, the harder their choices become.The game is more an interactive narrative, with lots of dialogue but there are also some light action scenes to break up the pacing. Your influence is largely felt through the choices you make, like you use your fists to beat clues out of a criminal instead of talking it out, or investigate one potential lead at the expense of another.The biggest accomplishment of The Wolf Among Us is that you really get a sense of what it is like to be Bigby. There are plenty of moments where a specific action will probably help you solve the crime, but ultimately make Fabletown residents hate you.The Wolf Among Us is a full interactive story.  As you progress along the narrative, you are also presented with choices. Each choice has consequences to the story which adapts based on the decisions you make.The visuals looks good. Overall the colours used are bright and appealing. The comic stylings manage to emulate the look of the books to a very high degree. The voice acting is amazing. Also the soundtrack is fantastic and really helps create the mood in the Wolf Among Us.The Wolf Among Us offer a great replayability, it is a fantastic game. I can completely recommend The Wolf Among Us to all who liked The Walking Dead from Telltale and also to all others.Sounds 10/10Graphics 8/10Gameplay 9/10Atmosphere 10/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

Posted: December 24, 2014
												I had played the first episode of this 5-episode series about a year ago and (as has become custom for me with Telltale’s episodic content) completely ignored it as episodes 2-4 came out.Picking up where I left off with episode 2, I plowed through the rest of the game yesterday. In addition to producing episodic content on a regular schedule with consistent quality (something few have mastered over the last couple decades) Telltale does a great job of summarizing previous episodes with their “previously on” segments. This made it easy for me to jump back in.All told, The Wolf Among Us was another excellent Telltale game, chock full of difficult choices and fun quick time events. Ultimately I feel that (compared to The Walking Dead) the decisions in The Wolf Among Us were easier to make. In The Walking Dead I feel like I’m always choosing between extremes, while the world of The Wolf Among Us is mired in layers of gray. In the end The Wolf Among Us was a great hard-boiled detective story with interesting characters, in an interesting world and I’m looking forward to another season should one come along.

												Unlike most, I waited until all chapters were released before playing - and I can understand some frustration in purchasing the content while it is being released.  Being able to play the entire story in one go was certainly worthwhile, and the story was amazing.  This is seriously a 5 star game.  You'll get drawn into the world, as well as the mystery and you won't want to play anything else until you're finished.  Game play itself isn't that long, and sadly it doesn't have any replay value (unless you want to try making differing decsions, which isn't as interesting as you know how everything turns out).  I would definately recommend this game, but as with all episodic content, wait till everything is released and play it all at once.  You'll be purchasing this game for the story - which certainly is at a high level of quality.

Posted: November 23, 2016
Basic OverviewStory? 7/10Controls? 5/10Replayability? 5/10Detailed ThoughtsI'm pretty sure this is my first Telltale game I've played and the first I've finished. It was a pretty solid story throughout - compelling, exciting, me wanting more (I thought it reminded me a lot of the TV show Once Upon a Time after the first episode). Then came the ending. It sucked. It came too quickly, it felt rushed, and it felt incomplete leaving many unanswered questions behind. It was unsatisfactory. I can't justify giving this game a thumbs down just because the last episode (there are 5 episodes in total) was awful, especially since the first four were amazing, but it's something to be mindful of. Moreover, if you're looking for a game where your choices actually impact the final outcome, this is probably not the game to play. Even though I've only done one run through, from the answer choices, it's easy to tell that your choices have little to no impact on the actual story - this is more like watching a TV show rather than playing a choice-matters game. On controls, maybe it's because this is my first Telltale game but the controls for moving your character were uncomfortable (FYI I'm using a keyboard); at some points it felt awkward to move around - the controls during the action cutscenes (attacking, etc.) were just fine and worked well. Regarding replayability, well like I've mentioned before, it felt like my choices didn't matter. While the story was compelling throughout until the very end, I don't feel the need to play it again and again until I've seen all the endings (heck, I'm not sure if there are any other endings or alternative routes), and probably the changes the choices make are minor and have little to no impact on the story. The only reason I'd see to replay this, is to unlock all the Book of Fables characters in the story (this consists of 5 achievements you can get). However, I'm not an achievement hunter and don't feel the need to do this, it would feel like a chore.Verdict?It's a solid story until the ending; the game doesn't really encourage replayability due to the little impact your choices make - so in my opinion, it's a one time run-through game.Worth at it's full price? Not really.Worth it if it's on sale? Eh, probably if you were interested and had this on your wishlistBundled? Lol, yes.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Telltale is killing it right now. I have a feeling their episodic games are going to have me addicted. This has the same gameplay and storytelling style as The Walking Dead. Telltale's developers have improved upon their combat and timing skills since they've made TWD.  The choice system gave you less time than in TWD. In TWD, you had enough time to think about the direction your response may take you which gave me a bias. In The Wolf Among Us you have just enough time to read the choices and decide. This lead to much more genuine gameplay on my part. Overall, I would highly recommend this game if you're a fan of The Walking Dead game style and you're cool with a storyline including characters from fairy tales.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												I love adventure games, and I love Western-style comic books and graphic novels. This is an adventure game based on a comic book series written by one of the principal writer's of Image Comics, 'The Walking Dead' series. The adaptation for television is now a blockbuster tv show. The gist of the 'Wolf Among Us', series is that Fables have been forced to update themselves in NYC, and you are the Big Bad Wolf, and Fabletown's Sheriff. There has been a murder in Fabletown, and as Sheriff you have to play the gumshoe and solve the case. Simple gameplay, with lots of story. Finally, your decisions, wise or otherwise, have a large effect on the results of the game. If you like the genre of this game, then its well worth the try.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												This game comes from the Telltale Games, creators of The Walking Dead games series and it feels pretty much the same. It's not a game per se. more like an interactive movie, with interactivity limited to several point-and-click scenes, a handful of QTE and a couple of plot-developing choices. However it still mananges to keep you glued to the screen for the (short) duration of the game. Its strenagth lies in the plot, setting and character design that feel like they came straight from the comic books. My main gripe wth the game is its price - for a two-hour experience it's a bit too much. Hopefully the DLC will come ant a discount

Posted: July 8, 2014
												Yet another incredible story driven game by Telltale ! If you're used to their games, the graphic and artistic styles won't comes as a surprise.I felt they really improved on this one. I specially appreciated how they depicted a dark but lively world, with magical creatures that try to adapt to live in our modern times and end up in the lowest part of our society.The story , a mature world, with sex and violence, gore and profanity. NSFW or whatever; is absolutely amazing. Well written with tons of mystery, it takes the Fables, all the classical, and put them together into a completely new context. All the characters that we encouter are charismatics, some of them even bringing in comedy; and i would have liked to know more about them to be honest. The voice over actors did a very good job, but unfortunately sound quality wasn't quite there. At least the music was great : the main theme is amazing for example, it just sticks in the head, but not in bad way.3 complaints i have : I felt that the game, on the overall, was too short, even after exploring most of the possibilities. There's not enough action or investigation moments, and unlike The walking dead or Back to the Future for example, i am not satisfied by what choices were offered.Secondly, QTE, i never liked them, but here they added frustration during my playthrough, either i didn't have time to type the right button at the right time, or i didn't mash Q fast enough. And sometimes, it's impossible to even do them so why bother ? I am not againts them, but QTE should be arranged in a way that is suited for this kind of game.And third, i fear that we won't be seeing a sequel anytime soon considering that TWD season 2 isn't finished and there are two new titles coming this very year from Telltale : Tales from the Borderlands and Game of Thrones. I am a bit curious about them but i can't say i appreciate seeing their other IPs probably getting delayed because of that. I am particulary sad they choosed to adapt Game of Throne, there is far too much hype around this about everywhere already.To conclude, I still have hope there will be some good news later this year. And I still have to get season 2 of The Walking Dead. But as of now, The Wolf Among Us is my new favorite Telltale game, and what makes it special for me, what makes it the best Telltale game as of yet ? Well, the one thing i really appreciate in a story is when i get to live most of the human feelings through it. And that is their only game that managed to do it so far.

Posted: December 28, 2014
												The wolf among us is an amazing adaptation of the comic series "Fables".The story in this is very captivating, and the way the player can control the choices using both dialogue and quick-time events really helps the immersion factor. It is also very in line with the tone that is set in the comics, with a good amount of humour thrown in as well. The characters are also well portrayed in this, if a little jumbled up because I don't beleive it uses the same canonical sequence of events.The art style in this game really captures the style of the comics, but in its own unique manner. I did see a few graphical issues while playing, but nothing major. Telltale also did a good job at converting the setting of the comics into a 3D environment, as well as continuing the style in adding new locations.The soundtrack in this game is brilliant. It does a good job at adding ambiance to the story, as well as the environments.I've only played the game once, but I do see a lot of replayability in the future, as there are plenty of choices that could affect the outcome of the entire story.Overall this game is well deserving of its awards, and definitely worth a buy if you want a game with a good story to it.

Posted: December 25, 2013
												This is a great interactive story that lets you choose how the story unfolds. If you are looking for lots of gameplay, then this may not be suited for you although playing through multiple times and making different choices is also fun to do to see how your actions affect the rest of the story line. I really like how the story has multiple scenarios that the player can choose to play through and that there is more weight on some descisions than others making for some interesting gameplay.The story in itself is very intriguing as you play as dectective Bigbie Wolf(The big bad wolf) trying to solve crimes around the fables in Fabletown.I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys story based games, murder mysteries, or point and click games. Play it for the story not the gameplay.

												This is honestly one of, if not the, best video games I have ever had the privilage of playing. It had me so emotinally involved that I was completely and utterly drained by the end of it and didn't have any idea of what to do next. Posted: July 9, 2014
												(9.5/10)I really was not sure what to expect out of this game.  I was not familair with the 'fables' source material, and enjoyed, but did not necessarily all-out love the prior telltale outings (sam & max, walking dead, etc).Well... 15 minutes in I pretty much was hooked.  The characters feel very well realized, and I was emotionally bound up in the story more deeply than I've been with a game in years.  The quicktime events are mildly frustrating, as they pretty much always will be in games, but this is no "Tomb Raider" and you can miss a few of those triggers now and again without it ruining the game for you.  The "silence is always an option" actually had me sometimes seriously sit back and wait, as the prepared responses simply didn't feel right, and generally the non action was more the action I felt was right and fit well.Certainly very highly reccomended on many levels for all who love adventure games, noir in general, and fables or other 'darker' ediger modern fairy tale stuff in general.  I dare you to not just play it all the way through... assuming you have the time of course.

Posted: July 8, 2014
												When I first heard of this game from a friend, I was like "Meh, maybe I'll check it out." A month later, my friend was still bothering me about it, so I watched the first episode of it via YouTube. In the first few minutes, I was absorbed. The game already had a good developing story line, and I LOVED the characters. At that one moment, I decided to give TTG all my money and buy The Wolf Among Us not only for one system, but for two (my Xbox 360 and my Steam). And now that the season is over, I can assure you all that this game is a work of art, and while I also thoroughly enjoyed the Walking Dead Series and S2 (Still currently enjoying) I can say that The Wolf Among Us definetley had a stronger feeling to it. I was the law, but I didn't get free donuts or anything. I got mean glares, and I got in trouble (frequently). I got to play the good guy, who wasn't popular or loved, but hated. I was the Big Bad Wolf, the sherriff, yet I still had life hard for me. And there was so much drama and suspense sometimes that the Wolf had to make descisions that would ruin him and any others. This really pulled me in, having a position so powerful and matching it with a character who doesn't always play by the rules and still had the ability to "Lose."The Wolf Among Us is for people who enjoy a good mystery, action, and  suspense. So yea, I highly recommend it, and you should all give TTG all of your money for making such a masterpiece like this. Bravo, TTG, Bravo.

												A very adult version of old Fables you read as a kid. Plays a lot like the next gen of the Telltales Walking Dead game. Lots of nostalgia here with a copious amount of gore, nudity and profanity. The game is very polished with cellshaded graphics. Each episode is about 2 hours long and the whole package deal gives you all 5 episodes.10/10 Amazing.

Posted: July 20, 2014
												The Wolf Among Us is another superb game by Telltale. I think the biggest testament I could give to it is that even though I spoiled the whole game for myself before actually buying it, I still went through it and finished it without complaints, in 5 days straight.Length-wise, it might not seem worth it; one playthrough took 9 hours for me. But these were 9 hours of superb entertainment. Hell, I even hooked up my TV up to my laptop, and to be fair, it was far better than anything that was actually on TV.Where do I begin? The story is really great, and it uncovers a bit more of the mystery in every episode -- just when you thought you knew everything, the game throws you a new curveball. Your choices might not matter that much (as in, the plot goes roughly the same direction whatever you do), but what's great about the game, is that most likely (unless you consciously try to play otherwise), you won't be a "black" or "white" character, if you will -- but you'll probably end up in one of the shades of "grey".The presentation is splendid. The Walking Dead (season 1, to be exact) had moments where graphics left some things to be desired, but Telltale really upped their ante here. The visuals feel like truly out of a comic book, with many vivid, lively colours around that, contrasting with the shadows, contribute to the noir-ish atmosphere. The sound is really good, as is the voice acting... but anyone who has played Walking Dead season 1 might find the re-use of the voice actors... pretty jarring.And for the end... the gameplay. It is a QTE-thon, if you will, but those QTEs really get you involved in the game and make the experience truly complete. The way the developers used quick-time events to represent your character's strength... it is really apparent, and is the last piece of the immersion puzzle.Overall, I strongly recommend The Wolf Among Us. It seems Telltale are not stepping off the right track, as I can't honestly say I've played one of their games I didn't enjoy so far.

												Tell tale have really hit their stride with this game.The graphics style lend its to the feel of the game to an even greater degree than in the walking dead series.It paints an amazing gritty noir story with the well executed twist of fables living in the mundane world.The voice acting and writing are impecable as ever and the engine has been optimised and runs even more smoothly than the Walking dead.One of the most engaging point and click games I have played in a long time, even better in my opinion than the Walking Dead games.

Posted: July 22, 2014
												The Tell Tale games are great when you just don't have the energy for other games.  They are like interactive movies that both enterain and engage.  I find the company's games perfect for a quiet night in where I can stuff my fae with food and still be able to easily engage in a game (I am not very good at multitasking food and games!).  The Wolf Among Us is based in the universe of the Fables comic book series.  It felt very true to the series for those who are big fans.  The first season surrounds a mysterious murder of a Fabletown inhabitant that the main character, Bigby Wolf (The Big Bad Wolf) encounters very early in the story.  There is mystery, murder, magic, and fantasy as well as some good old fashioned gore.  There are several plot twists that are quite catching.I personally look forward to another season of this series.  I have enjoyed it just as much as The Walking Dead.  It's a different genre but the story gets better and better as you go.  It's been years since I really have enjoyed point-click story games.  Tell Tale Games has done a great job with everything I have played of theirs so far.  Even if it is not my cup of tea, I have picked up their games and always found myself enjoying the story.  I hope you will give this one a chance.  You may fight yourself pleasantly surprised by the darkness twisted into our childhood tales.

Posted: July 25, 2014
												Wolf Among Us is easily one of the single best video games I've ever had the chance to play, and has stuck with me after beating it like only a few games before it had *Games like Halo 1 when I was still feeling the pre-pubecent sting of young adult hood or Kotor with its many branching paths plus emphasis upon ones actions*.  A combination of maltese falcon meets the wire, Wolf Among Us firmly places the player into the shoes of gruff no nonsense sheriff Bigby Wolf as he has to navigate the seedy underworld of fabletown amidst the squalor of 1980's New York to either reaffirm himself as king supreme of bad dudes everywhere or as a miscast man trying to make up for the pain he's inflicted upon his fellow fables in years past. If you love crime drama's and have a taste for the strange, then I whole heartedly recommend this game. For that matter I can't help but recommend this game to everyone willing to divest their time in a good story driven by player choice and the consequences that follow! 10/10 Dogecoins

												tl;dr scoreboard:+ Great characters, awesome voice acting+ The Fables universe is fascinating+ Interesting plot- Not a whole lot of gameplay- Storyline doesn't really branch, so choices made don't feel that meaningful- Oh, how I wish it was a bit longer!Telltale do what Telltale do best: They've created an AMAZING story in a really interesting universe (Fables). Posted: July 27, 2015
												Extremely entertaining, thus said, this is not a game... It is a story that has been "gamified", meaning that, it has interactive momments, but it is mainly just an animated series.The story is a completely different take on classic fables. Snow white, beauty and the beast, big bad wolf (what you play as), etc. They now live in the real world, with real problems...First of all, for those expecting action, there isnt much. Some reaction buttons here and there, but like i said, its mainly an animated series with a couple of player interactions. Not like "Shenmue", so dont worry about having to be fast lol... About mechanics and what you can do? Well, you pick frases and actions everynow and then, that sometimes affects the storyline but usually just affects the outcome of the conversation... slightly...  What i should point out, is that this action/words choice, is not like bioware games. It definetly doesn't change the game as much, but it will make you think more.The choices here are emotional, it is not about the item you want or how you want to behave, but more about how you react emotionally. They feel important and heavier. Mainly because this game is a drama and there is a time to pick your choice, so that it feels like an actual conversation. Wierdly enough, you will feel realism here, eventhough its cartoonish and 105% fiction.It is a refreshing and original experience that earned TellTale their name and fame. Imo the best game they have, since it  works ontop of classic children fables while bringing a police/drama theme. Will "magically" distort your reality a few times, making you react in ways you would and wouldn't...

												One of the things I appreciated right from the start of A Wolf Among Us is its unique premise.  I was genuinely hooked from the beginning.  Similar to The Walking Dead, they drop you into the middle of a layered situation which creates a lot of questions in your mind which, in part, compells you to play more to gain the answers.  They did a really good job at gradually feeding you bits of information while at the same time creating more questions, it felt like a good ratio.  Because of this, A Wolf Among Us never stopped being exciting to play.  Having also played The Walking Dead it is actually somewhat difficult for me to decide which I liked more; that's high praise.

Posted: September 2, 2014
												My rating for The Wolf Among Us is four stars. It narrowly misses out on top marks due to the above-mentioned technical hiccups. It also feels like Telltale is just emulating Walking Dead’s winning formula instead of innovating. If I had to compare the two, I would say that Walking Dead made more of an emotional impact on me. The Wolf Among Us however edges out the contest for most colourful characters, thanks to its cast of fairy tale stars. Story wise I would say that TWAU is the better of the two, as its mystery yarn is more interesting than a zombie apocalypse tale. TWAU also has a powerful ending, which trumps Walking Dead’s “fishing for a season two” finale. Should Telltale ever abandon video game production they should consider entering the marketing business instead. Just like The Walking Dead, after finishing The Wolf Among Us I am interested in sampling the comic it is based off. They are in effect making interactive adverts that I am happy to buy!

Posted: May 8, 2015
												One of Telltale's best games.  This is where they solidified their formula, and presented us with some of the most riveting and engaging story-driven gameplay yet produced.Wat for this one to go on sale, as it seems to happen quite often, and nab all five episodes.  The story is second to none, the art style is amazing, and the voice acting SHOULD have been award-winning.  This is a game that treats you like an adult, and plays so well and so smoothly that you'll be driven to complete the story.  There is even a fair amount of replay value to try out different choices and see how the story changes.  Sure, the big story doesn't change that much, but just like life, it's the little things around you, and the people you directly interact with that can make enough differences to keep you coming back, and playing a different Bigby many times.

If you've never heard of the comic series it is based on, 'Fables', that's fine. I hadn't either, and I still enjoyed the game immensely. In fact, I enjoyed it so much I'm tempted to go out and find the first issue of the comics and give it a try. Not gonna spoil anything, but I will say that the game reels you in as the episodes go on, before yanking you in and out at the end. The guys over at TellTale did a REALLY good job with the visual presentation on this, and personally... I prefer it over TWD games. I know, shoot me now. But I REALLY LOVED THIS. And I loved TWD too! But I still have to admit it that it didn't suck me in to it's world as much as TWAU did for me. If you haven't played a TellTale games episodic, then I whole-heartedly recommend starting here. And if you have, yet haven't picked this up... I'm just gonna give you a questioning look over the internet now. Yep. Can you feel it? That's the stare of questioning. Well enough staring, I'm gonna go to bed... Pick up the game though. Seriously. It's amazing. Tenouttaten.

Posted: January 17, 2015
												Wowzers, two chapters in and I adore this game.  I am a Fables fan, so that would nearly be enough to please me, and I've enjoyed other Tell Tale games, but this exceeds both of those factors in spades.  The writing? Great, entirely up to Fables standards, and unique enough to stand on its own.  The visuals?  Comic-like, yet fluid and dark and vibrant, and just, wow, it's what I've always envisioned when I though of pulp and noir at the same time.  The gameplay?  The best I've ever experiences in a Tell Tale game.  Everything I loved about the first season of Tell Tale's Walking Dead. only better, if possible!  I love this game!  My only complaint?  I wish I had more time to play it!  Now... bed at a reasonable hour... or another episode... hm...

Posted: July 10, 2014
												Ok where do I start. Smart Brutal Noir Masterpiece 10/10. If you are going to buy this, you are so lucky you don’t have to wait a Full year to get from Episode 1 to Episode 5, but the wait For Season 2 will kill you. I am a fan of the Comics since I was very young and was angry and hopeful about Telltale messing with one of my favorite comics, but Telltale deliver on their own brand of Quality and Respect the source material as they create their own universe around it. As a very Noir Game, This is a Detective story in the real world with a Fairytale cast, and you will soon find out there is no such thing as Happily Ever After. The Story will abuse your personals feelings, play with your mind, and test your own sense of morality. How far are you willing to go for answers? Did you do the right choices? Why are you really doing this? Who can you trust? Are you the Big Bad Wolf? If you ever want to make the case of Video Game=Art, this should be in your list. Can’t wait for Season 2

Posted: July 11, 2014
												Good Lord this game has a fantastic story. From the moral descisions you have to make in the space of a few seconds, the tense action scenes, and the well-written dialoge (both from the characters and your own character) make this an absolutely superb story-telling adventure.In the Telltale Games style, it is mostly a point-and-click adventure, but it's so much more than that. The colors are vivid, and in this particular case, sometimes oversaturated to give the feel of NYC and to make it look much like the Fables graphic novels came to life. The voice acting is just as good.You play as Bigby Wolf, the Big Bad Wolf of ye bedtime stories of old, turned sherriff of Fabletown, a small neighborhood in New York City. A murder (or two...or three...or four) has just happened in the most gruesom fashion, and you're given the task of finding out who committed it, and why. It's up to you if you'll be the bad cop, or the good cop, who your suspects are, who you'll convict, and, if proven guilty, their sentence.The story is based on the characters of the Fables graphic novels and so you'll meet characters you already know (albiet with a very different personality then you remember) such as Snow White, Tweedle Dee and Tweedle Dum, Ichabod Crane, Belle and Beast, and Bloody Mary, just to name a few. Some characters that were "good" in the fairy tales are now a little shady, and others that were shady are now (seemingly) trustworthy. While it is certainly not necessary to read the graphic novels to understand and appreciate the characters and the story of this masterpiece, I think it'd be worth your time to pick up the first three issues or so and read them, just to get a feel for the characters and their personalities. They're free the internet somewhere, so no extra cost.But I digress. Top-tier story, sublime voice acting, gripping action scenes, beautiful artwork, and excellent dialogue and dialouge choices make this a definite purchase even if you're barely contemplating it.

Posted: July 8, 2014
												Yet another incredible story driven game by Telltale ! If you're used to their games, the graphic and artistic styles won't comes as a surprise.I felt they really improved on this one. I specially appreciated how they depicted a dark but lively world, with magical creatures that try to adapt to live in our modern times and end up in the lowest part of our society.The story , a mature world, with sex and violence, gore and profanity. NSFW or whatever; is absolutely amazing. Well written with tons of mystery, it takes the Fables, all the classical, and put them together into a completely new context. All the characters that we encouter are charismatics, some of them even bringing in comedy; and i would have liked to know more about them to be honest. The voice over actors did a very good job, but unfortunately sound quality wasn't quite there. At least the music was great : the main theme is amazing for example, it just sticks in the head, but not in bad way.3 complaints i have : I felt that the game, on the overall, was too short, even after exploring most of the possibilities. There's not enough action or investigation moments, and unlike The walking dead or Back to the Future for example, i am not satisfied by what choices were offered.Secondly, QTE, i never liked them, but here they added frustration during my playthrough, either i didn't have time to type the right button at the right time, or i didn't mash Q fast enough. And sometimes, it's impossible to even do them so why bother ? I am not againts them, but QTE should be arranged in a way that is suited for this kind of game.And third, i fear that we won't be seeing a sequel anytime soon considering that TWD season 2 isn't finished and there are two new titles coming this very year from Telltale : Tales from the Borderlands and Game of Thrones. I am a bit curious about them but i can't say i appreciate seeing their other IPs probably getting delayed because of that. I am particulary sad they choosed to adapt Game of Throne, there is far too much hype around this about everywhere already.To conclude, I still have hope there will be some good news later this year. And I still have to get season 2 of The Walking Dead. But as of now, The Wolf Among Us is my new favorite Telltale game, and what makes it special for me, what makes it the best Telltale game as of yet ? Well, the one thing i really appreciate in a story is when i get to live most of the human feelings through it. And that is their only game that managed to do it so far.

Posted: April 10, 2015
AUDIOMoodyVISUALComic BookDIFFICULTYEasyVIBENoirCRAVINGInteractive FictionON SALEOccasionallyPROS: Great action scenes and an interesting story. The artsier parts (openings, transitions) have a gorgeous 80's style with moody color schemes, though they seem to taper off per episode (I certainly hope they become more frequent in season 2!) The "fairy tale reboot" is one of the most annoying things to have started in recent years, and yet still I did not mind this at all. The voices and animation/models are excellent. Climax is very enjoyable.CONS: : I actually ran into two glitches in Ep 5 that required restarts from previous checkpoints. That was very surprising, for a game that has you on rails from start to finish. Some QTEs have absolutely no bearing on what happens (No success or failure until you move forward.) Not much of a QTE, eh? Alongside the lack of failures and deadends, this first season does not branch very much, story-wise. While discovering that through replays, I found the save files to be a bit confusing.WORTH: The chances of a season 2 seem increasingly slim. It'd be a little sad to start in on a series nobody has any intention on finishing.OVERALL: The cliffhanger ending may be infuriating, but I'm pumped for season 2 and plan to buy the episodes on release (if that ever happens.) I'd love to see consequences having more weight in the coming games.SCORE: 8/10                                                                     Full Review Coming Soon

Posted: January 8, 2016
												The Wolf Among Us makes improvements in two areas over The Walking Dead, those being technical and presentation. Technically the game is much smoother, and is totally free the character stutter that plagued The Walking Dead, especially in season one. The other noticeable improvement was the HUD, it's far cleaner and just much nicer to look at now, the on-screen prompts were also well done and clearer to see.What put this game over The Walking Dead for me was the setting, I absolutely loved it! It was basically Once Upon a Time sprinkled with Grimm and I'm all over that. The story was well written which I've come to expect from Teltale and you were constantly left guessing right up until the end, I am still confused about what actually happened 30 minutes later, which honestly I didn't like, I much prefer clear cut endings over the whole "let the player decide what really happened", it's like the cinema shutting off the tape 5 minutes before the end and telling you to imagine the ending. That being said it didn't hurt the game and I have my own theory!Teltale have opened my eyes to a genre I never explored before and I thank them for that, I have been really enjoying just sitting back and relaxing in bed deciding people's fates in these interactive films.

Posted: September 5, 2014
												The Wolf Among Us is very familiar if you have played The Walking Dead.  The game is more like an interactive story and it is very difficult to fail or 'lose'.  It is an ambiguous detective tale involving anti heroes, prostitution, murder and some hard choices.  It fails in terms of challenging gameplay, but it's not really about that.  The game excels in graphics, art direction, voice acting and story.  The game is split into 5 episodes and some of them are certainly stronger than others.  I can certainly recommend this game for its positives as I've mentioned and despite it not being difficult or challenging, it has an interesting story that is worth following from episode 1 to episode 5.  It is a high quality game and I found it to be an excellent one to throw on when I didn't really want to have to concentrate on a more difficult game.So try The Wolf Among Us if you are interested in games like The Walking Dead, but make sure you are not looking for any puzzles or real challenge.  It's a good story and could certainly give some modern TV shows a run for their money and that's the main reason I would recommend this game.

Posted: January 9, 2016
												This is a pretty fun murder mystery story set around the late '80s where characters from fairy tales have a little community in New York. Even though the game is mostly point-and-click, the action sequences are a little bit different to mix things up.The only downsides I found were the last two episodes being very short; it would have made more sense if they combined the two into a single episode considering the time it takes to complete each of the first three. The other thing is your choices only seem to affect whatever is happening in that moment and don't really have a noticeable impact on the story being told.I found it to be enjoyable enough to play through three times to see the other characters' reactions: once as a good guy, once as a jerk, and the last saying as little as the game would allow me to. It only needs to be played through a single time, but if you want all of the achievements, certain parts need to be played differently (make the opposite choice, go to a different location first, etc.) so you can grab those last few fable entries.Overall, this game isn't Telltale's best work but it's definitely worth picking up when it goes on sale.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												Telltale has done it again. Wolf Among Us is a brilliant story-driven fairytale noire adventure game masterpiece. You play as Bigby Wolf, sole defender of a town of exiled characters from fairy tales, folklore, and other literature. It's clear from the beginning that Bigby cares about the job and the people he protects. However, the laws of Fabletown aren't making him any friends, since any Fable who can't afford a very expensive Glamour to hide their unnatural appearance is sent to The Farm - the equivalent of a life sentence in prison. When a murder investigation goes sideways, Bigby has to pick up the pieces of a town brought to its knees by corruption, inequality, and despair. His hot temper has earned him a reputation for ruthlessness. Maybe some folks just can't let go of the stories they left behind in the story books. Or maybe they all still have good reason to fear the Big Bad Wolf.If you like making game-changing decisions at a moment's notice, and don't mind sacrificing traditional adventure game puzzles for a story that grabs you by the hand and runs, then you will love this game. Also, if you enjoy a second playthrough once you know the story, the many choices available to you make it worthwhile.

												This game took me approx 7 hours to finish, and overall its a solid 5/7 for me.Wolf Among Us is an Adventure, Point & Click game, but actually, It resembles more of a visual novel for me, not always of course, but most of the game. Why?- Yes there are outcomes of your choices, like people may like you more, or you may try to make a particular someone to make you like you, or just be a jerk. But the thing is, your overall choices doesn't really effect the outcome of the main storyline. You can sometimes choose if a person is going to be killed or not, but that doesn't change the actual storyline, it adds pepper and salt.So;PROS: - Art & sounds are great. I like the artstyle a lot actually, its alluring.- Story is thrilling. There will be lots of question marks and gasps, believe me.- Gameplay, well, I like visual novels, but point and click games are annoying for me most of the time. I'm not really good at making connections so item based ones are always a pain for me. But this game is actually easier, you can clearly see what you can click, there are not much to use. This can be CON to someone probably but you can close the visual of clickables.- Characters. FABLEEEEES. Great set of characters.- It's definetely not children friendly, but its makes appealing for me heh. Some gore and blood and♥♥♥♥♥♥makes the game a lots more visual.CONS:- If you're more of a detective type, this can be a little bit easy for you. Not in terms of story, but in terms of gameplay.- As I said, you can't really change the somethings, even though you made a choice against that particular something.Overall: Get this, It gets %70~75 sale on recent sales and its a great game.

Posted: March 31, 2015
												Well first of all I'd like to say that I got this game as a gift, I have seen my friend play the 4th episode before so I wouldn't have bought it myself, but after completing the game, I've changed my mind. The game tells a story about sheriff Bigby Wolf and his attepmts to solve the mysterious murder of a working girl. The game's characters are from various fairytales living in a place called Fabletown. The characters are all really unique and interesting, you wouldn't imagine them living their lives as criminals or alcoholics etc., as you may expect them to be heroic and mighty. The stoy in The Wolf Among Us is very interesting and has a lot of twists. There are a lot of quick time events that I've enjoyed doing. Interacting with people in various ways will affect how they interact with you, your choices really matter. If you're looking for a game with a great story, I'd defintely recommend  buying this game.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												NOTE: This review was written before Episode 5: Cry Wolf was released. This review may be revised, at a later date.Alright, so I just got done with playing this game, so it's pretty fresh in memory for me. I've never read any of the Fables comics before playing, but I gotta say: This game really has me interested. It's like someone took the concept of Shrek and gave it a more mature, more modern spin to it.Well, as I start discussing gameplay, I'll go ahead and say this now: If you don't like point-and-click adventures, don't buy this game. This game may not change your general thoughts about the genre. For those who are still here: The game's mechanics are pretty much lifted from Skybound/Telltale's own The Walking Dead game, so you should know what those are like, if you've played those games already. If not: You mostly go around certain areas of the game, clicking on stuff to examine it, talk to people, or use items. You also get sections where you must escape peril by means of Quick-Time Events. The game is also heavy in cutscenes with selectable dialogue, which you're having to select before a timer runs out. What choice you make and when you make it will affect minor details of the story, like what a certain character will remember about you or what event may occur next. Either way, like with The Walking Dead, the game's story is still linear and never really branches off into a path, unless you count the choices you make.The story here is really great, I gotta say. You play as Bigby Wolf (the Big Bad Wolf of fairy tales), and you are teamed up with Snow White to investigate a serial murder that's been going on in Fabletown, with hopes of ending it before another victim is claimed. You and Snow White meet a lot of fairy tale characters along the way, who are all connected to the murder case in some way. The way characters remember your previous actions and use that alongside other story elements in their character development is really excellent, though your choices are still minor development for them. Oh yeah, the story's pretty great, too. Not spoiling anything, so why don't you play for yourself? XDThe graphic style...I LOVE IT! Okay basically, they took the graphic style of The Walking Dead and gave it a much more colorful and contrasting lighting system, to give it a much better comic book style. Lots of blacks to give it that dark, mature feeling, mixed in with a whole lot of vibrant colors to aid in that comic book feel that I mentioned, which some unique outline effects for when an object is covered up in a shadow. I'm at loss for words here. All I can say is that I just love it. I want more games with this kind of graphical style DXThe voice acting in this game, as expected of a Telltale game, is phenominal...albeit hard to hear, if you don't have headphones plugged in. Okay, this part really gets on my nerves: I don't like it when the voice acting in a movie/game/TV show is so quiet that I have to turn the volume up, and then all the sound effects are so loud that I have to turn it back down. Sadly, it's the case with this game, too. I wish there was better balance with multimedia productions, with this stuff. But regardless, I really like the dialogue spoken in the game, and the voice actors chosen for each of the characters really fit well with the character and what they say. Oh yeah, the musical score's pretty neat, too.This game has some replayability, though you're always going to get the same story every time. Some parts may be different based on your choices, but that's about it. I guess that may be worth it, if not to collect the Book of Fables entries, but it won't be for everyone.Overall, I really enjoyed this game. Mechanics-wise, it does feel like a step above of The Walking Dead, though maybe not that much. May be more noticable in a second playthrough. Either way, if you really enjoy the Fables comics or Telltale's games, or you just want a good point-and-click game with an engrossing story, pick this game up.

Posted: January 3, 2015
												I didn't know much about The Wolf Among Us going into it other than that it was based on a comic book series, however not much background was needed. Prior knowledge of the Fables universe is not necessary as the events of the game happen before those in the comic book series. The story is also relatively straightforward and easy to follow while still managing to capture your interest- the cliffhangers at each episode's end made it imposible to wait before playing the next, so I'm glad I purchased the game once it was released in its entirety; I don't think I would have enjoyed it as much had I been forced to wait months for each new episode. The only real complaint I have about the game is the playing time. I finished it in about eight hours, and it has little replay value as it focuses more on story than on actual gameplay (the game is essentially point and click dialogue, with a few battle scenes that are near impossible to lose). I would not buy this game at full price for the short playing time alone, however I thoroughly enjoyed it and would definitely recommend it as a sale purchase.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												The Wolf Among Us is one of the finest examples of story in a video game that I have seen in my 20 years of gaming.Like other Telltale Games hit, The Walking Dead, the sheer amount of choices available to the player, both in your dialog options as well as your ability to choose to threaten, maim, or even kill many of the characters you interact with gives the player a game that they can play several times over and still find new and interesting aspects of the story to uncover.There is not a single thing not to love about this title. Posted: July 8, 2014
												When I first heard of this game from a friend, I was like "Meh, maybe I'll check it out." A month later, my friend was still bothering me about it, so I watched the first episode of it via YouTube. In the first few minutes, I was absorbed. The game already had a good developing story line, and I LOVED the characters. At that one moment, I decided to give TTG all my money and buy The Wolf Among Us not only for one system, but for two (my Xbox 360 and my Steam). And now that the season is over, I can assure you all that this game is a work of art, and while I also thoroughly enjoyed the Walking Dead Series and S2 (Still currently enjoying) I can say that The Wolf Among Us definetley had a stronger feeling to it. I was the law, but I didn't get free donuts or anything. I got mean glares, and I got in trouble (frequently). I got to play the good guy, who wasn't popular or loved, but hated. I was the Big Bad Wolf, the sherriff, yet I still had life hard for me. And there was so much drama and suspense sometimes that the Wolf had to make descisions that would ruin him and any others. This really pulled me in, having a position so powerful and matching it with a character who doesn't always play by the rules and still had the ability to "Lose."The Wolf Among Us is for people who enjoy a good mystery, action, and  suspense. So yea, I highly recommend it, and you should all give TTG all of your money for making such a masterpiece like this. Bravo, TTG, Bravo.

Posted: January 3, 2015
												I didn't know much about The Wolf Among Us going into it other than that it was based on a comic book series, however not much background was needed. Prior knowledge of the Fables universe is not necessary as the events of the game happen before those in the comic book series. The story is also relatively straightforward and easy to follow while still managing to capture your interest- the cliffhangers at each episode's end made it imposible to wait before playing the next, so I'm glad I purchased the game once it was released in its entirety; I don't think I would have enjoyed it as much had I been forced to wait months for each new episode. The only real complaint I have about the game is the playing time. I finished it in about eight hours, and it has little replay value as it focuses more on story than on actual gameplay (the game is essentially point and click dialogue, with a few battle scenes that are near impossible to lose). I would not buy this game at full price for the short playing time alone, however I thoroughly enjoyed it and would definitely recommend it as a sale purchase.

												I love adventure games, and I love Western-style comic books and graphic novels. This is an adventure game based on a comic book series written by one of the principal writer's of Image Comics, 'The Walking Dead' series. The adaptation for television is now a blockbuster tv show. The gist of the 'Wolf Among Us', series is that Fables have been forced to update themselves in NYC, and you are the Big Bad Wolf, and Fabletown's Sheriff. There has been a murder in Fabletown, and as Sheriff you have to play the gumshoe and solve the case. Simple gameplay, with lots of story. Finally, your decisions, wise or otherwise, have a large effect on the results of the game. If you like the genre of this game, then its well worth the try.

Posted: July 27, 2015
												Extremely entertaining, thus said, this is not a game... It is a story that has been "gamified", meaning that, it has interactive momments, but it is mainly just an animated series.The story is a completely different take on classic fables. Snow white, beauty and the beast, big bad wolf (what you play as), etc. They now live in the real world, with real problems...First of all, for those expecting action, there isnt much. Some reaction buttons here and there, but like i said, its mainly an animated series with a couple of player interactions. Not like "Shenmue", so dont worry about having to be fast lol... About mechanics and what you can do? Well, you pick frases and actions everynow and then, that sometimes affects the storyline but usually just affects the outcome of the conversation... slightly...  What i should point out, is that this action/words choice, is not like bioware games. It definetly doesn't change the game as much, but it will make you think more.The choices here are emotional, it is not about the item you want or how you want to behave, but more about how you react emotionally. They feel important and heavier. Mainly because this game is a drama and there is a time to pick your choice, so that it feels like an actual conversation. Wierdly enough, you will feel realism here, eventhough its cartoonish and 105% fiction.It is a refreshing and original experience that earned TellTale their name and fame. Imo the best game they have, since it  works ontop of classic children fables while bringing a police/drama theme. Will "magically" distort your reality a few times, making you react in ways you would and wouldn't...

Posted: July 24, 2015
 The Wolf Among Us was one of the best games of 2014, and arguabely stands as Telltale's best game to date. I was first cautious to purchase this game. It was based on a source material that I knew nothing about, and seemingly featured fantastical themes which weren't really my 'thing' - werewolves, fairytales and the like. However, I took the plunge when episode five was released and I didn't look back.The Wolf Among Us is sleek, atmospheric, and out-right dark in places. Based on the comic  Fables , you play as Bigby wolf,  the  big bad wolf, sheriff and protector of Fabletown, a community of 'fables' and mythical creatures in New York after their banishment from their own world. A murder has occured, and you must put the pieces of the puzzle together to find the culprit. Without spoiling any more, The Wolf Among Us grows with every episode, the stakes become higher as Bigby uncovers more than he could have imagined from a single murder case, until the intense finale of episode five. The story is superbly written, the characters interesting and well developed - some of which you become very attached to. The environments are extemely atmospheric, and the music compliments them very well (the soundtrack is  amazing! ). The puzzels are fun, although not too challenging, and as with most Telltale titles take a back seat in favour of branching dialogue. All combat is QTE, which is done alright with this game, but I know many people get annoyed with these controls - point and click isn't for everyone! Overall it is a fantastic adventure game worth paying for, in my opinion level with Walking Dead Season 1. Tentitive to purchase it primarily, but now I am a fully-fledged fan of the game.  This is worth buying at full price - especially if you loved The Walking Dead. You will love this too!  One final word on people's biggest moan about Telltale: choices. "Your choices don't matter...they don't affect the plot...it's all an illusion" is what is said all of the time in comments. While it is true they don't affect the plot in drastic ways, they affect two things: the protagonist, and the player. The protagonists in all Telltale games are shaped by your choices. Will Lee be a hopeful person, and try and teach Clementine to hold onto the old ways of civility? Or will he adapt, and teach her survival at any cost. Similarly Bigby can try and prove himself to be a caring and decent sheriff, or live up to his name as the big bad wolf. Finally the player is shaped by the choices: your perception of the game/story will change depending on what you pick, how you feel about other characters, how you feel about yourself, and, for me anyway, they stick with me and undoubtedly change my mindset for the rest of the game. So yes, the choices do have value, just not really plot-wise, which seems to be the only thing which matters to some people.

Posted: September 2, 2014
												My rating for The Wolf Among Us is four stars. It narrowly misses out on top marks due to the above-mentioned technical hiccups. It also feels like Telltale is just emulating Walking Dead’s winning formula instead of innovating. If I had to compare the two, I would say that Walking Dead made more of an emotional impact on me. The Wolf Among Us however edges out the contest for most colourful characters, thanks to its cast of fairy tale stars. Story wise I would say that TWAU is the better of the two, as its mystery yarn is more interesting than a zombie apocalypse tale. TWAU also has a powerful ending, which trumps Walking Dead’s “fishing for a season two” finale. Should Telltale ever abandon video game production they should consider entering the marketing business instead. Just like The Walking Dead, after finishing The Wolf Among Us I am interested in sampling the comic it is based off. They are in effect making interactive adverts that I am happy to buy!

Posted: July 2, 2015
												Becuase this game has been reviewed in a positive and beaming light so many times, I'll forego discussing its pros and cons and instead depart my impression of the experience.A gruff man who took the mantle of the only authority in a beat-up city that can enforce the law had me sold off the bat, but mixing it with a sincere backstory of his attempt to redeem himself throughout the murder mystery itself was honestly the best canon I could've hoped for in a game like this.The moral options that you're given in this game can really surprise you with their outcome; quite a few of them have no serious repurcussions such as taking money from Georgie's safe, Crane's coat pocket, the package at the Tweedles' office, etc. I found it great, because it can really help you decide what kind of moral road you'll be taking through the game by deciding what you'd do when no one's looking or going to burn you for it.This is the kind of character development anyone should crave if you seek moral development and/or redemption in a relatable setting.SPOILER BELOWI haven't seen any reviews that mention it yet, but I'm almost positive this game mind♥♥♥♥ed me in the end. Here's why:When Nerissa begins to walk away in the epilogue, Bigby begins remembering all the things she's said that were almost identical to what Faith said in the first chapter. All because of the phrase "you're not as bad as they say you are."It's incredible to think that Nerissa, who lied to incriminate and convict the Crooked Man, claims to have placed Faith's head at the Woodlands entrance, and claims to have sold out and watched Faith die, is heavily hinted to either be Faith or somehow an alternate version of her or something. After all, Swineheart never gave results on Faith's body. No one knows what ended up happening to the Donkeyskin Coat. She also refused to take the ribbon off.The biggest hint of all for me was the fact that when other characters such as Lily and the Crooked Man would ask for your initial motive, you always had the option (which I always took) to say that it was all for Faith. That's just too big to ignore. Regrettably, I didn't save Prince Lawrence in my plathrough, so I don't know if and what that alters.

Posted: July 10, 2014
 The Wolf Among Us  A Film Noir Drama, that loudly goes nowhere.. (I realise that this will easily be the most controversial piece that i have ever written, but you cannot archieve fame/notoriety without being a bit of a tosser.)Well, that subtext kinda reveals my point without explaining. I have a right tonne of stuff to nitpick.. However, i'm not going to fight hyperactive fanboys over this point. Instead of fighting, i'm just going to point out the problems in this particular series. Whilst attempting to cut out all the possible spoilers and trying to tie everything in to a cohesive critique..( All whilst suffering from bronchitis and tanking painkillers. ) The review has a lot of references to the Graphic novel series, so unless you have read them. Please refrain from posting bad arguments. The game starts in a way that i find very solid, like in the graphic novels. (Yes, i have now read all the books.) But unlike the novels, the game seems to have a rather obvious pacing problem. Maybe due to the episodic nature, but before you nag about it being the same in the novels. The novels had a very clear notion of what is happening, having an isolated short story in each issue and having small hints for what might happen next.The game attempts this storytelling method, but manages to muck it up slightly.. Or moderately. This is the part where i turn very biased, so if you excuse me for a minute...TellTale has a reputation of making some very good episodic titles, one of my personal favourites being the Sam & Max series. But no matter how well you manage to create a story and setting for the characters in question, there are always some lurches that manage to appear. Sam & Max fans know what i'm talking about here.. That certain episode that was listed as "A waste of time" even by Sam & Max themselves. These lurches appear usually when you have "Too many irons in the furnace". If i managed to translate that correctly, or if that metaphor didn't work. Lets just say "Having too big of a sip from an icy slushie and getting a brainfreeze". Having too much stuff that you can actually manage. Causing everything they do, a little half-baked. And by that i mean; A raw slob of dough that you kept in the oven for only 15-Minutes and though it was properly cooked. Wow! My metaphors are terrible when i'm sick.. But back to review before i get distracted more...Like i was trying to explain, by my metaphorically deprived way; The game is not that good. I took some time to discuss this problem with one of my friends and we came to a conclusion that the pacing was off. Amongst other things..So the "friends video-game club discussion" that we had, came to a conclusion that the games pacing was along the lines of a badly edited TV-Programme. Starting in a solid way, then getting cut as everything got interesting and after that filling some time faffing about, then finally ending in a cliffhanger. Oh f*ck! i just spoiled the ending.And speaking of the ending, after spoiling the cilffhanger. Its one of those endings that gives closure to the story, but explains absolutely NOTHING. The game already had some holes in its plot like a colinder has for flour,  Why am i fixated on baking all of the sudden?  and none of those thing are even remotely explained during the ending. The rest is a bit of a spoiler, so i'l black it out for you..  The ending that is the one chatting up to Nerissa, explains nothing more than the things connected to Lily the first murder victim. Nerissa explains, that it was her who left the head in front of the Woodlands Building. Bridging in the missing pieces on how she died, but thats it.  So even with that ending, i felt confused and dazed. Since i felt, as i mentioned, that nothing was explained.And those are the problems i have with this particular series. I'm not going to copy-paste the usual, "Great visuals" "Marvellous atmosphere" And all the other faff. Since you know (if you have read any of my other reviews) i don't really give a damn about visual style.I just realised, that i really haven't been writing a review. Rather i have written a long line of nitpicking.. But even with being a nitpick, it still has a decent point and the point being: "The game had terrible pacing, some obvious plotholes and an ending that explains nothing." And i cannot do nothing else but to get annoyed at the fact that TellTale are going to attempt to explain the stuff in the second season, if there even will be one..But all my narking aside..The Wolf Among Us, is a quirky but enjoyable story set in the Fables universe. But i cannot really recommend it over the books, but i will recommend it as a spinoff title, even with its problems.Rating? i quess.. Thinking about it, as my painkiller buffed brain can cope.I think a reasonable B+ is in order.Reasons being: plotholes, pacing issues, the ending and TellTales time management.

Posted: July 6, 2014
												I have to say I'm terribly pleased that Telltale Games have finally decided to compose an adventure set in this delightful universe, it must also be added that I greatly approve of the direction the company is heading. TWAU is a wonderful story that's both strangely comic and poignant; it's imbued with a sort of breezy, heart filled spirit which begins in episode one and endures throughout all the subsequent episodes. I also like that there are many ancillary characters who are unapologetic about their lack of conscience, and who don't seem to suffer in consequence. The inclusion of adult subtexts such as adultery and prostitution is a pleasant surprise to those who are unfamiliar with the comics. I've personally enjoyed the game and sincerely hope that Telltale Games continue with the franchise.9/10

												Much like The Walking Dead, "The Wolf Among Us" is based on a popular comic book series that uses many of the same features and art style. I'll be honest, I never completed TWD game, but I have a far greater urge to witness the next installment of this five part series. Once again, TellTale has gone for the interactive story style of "gameplay" and your choices affect the outcome. You "play" as Bigby Wolf(Big Bad Wolf) and attempt to solve a complex murder mystery. For a good two hours expect to mash the 'E' key repeatedly, and choose your words quickly yet carefully. If you enjoyed the "Fable" comics or looking for something similar to TWD, pick this up for $25. Though we all know how Steam is. You can always wait for a deal, or until all the episodes are released.

Posted: December 28, 2014
												The wolf among us is an amazing adaptation of the comic series "Fables".The story in this is very captivating, and the way the player can control the choices using both dialogue and quick-time events really helps the immersion factor. It is also very in line with the tone that is set in the comics, with a good amount of humour thrown in as well. The characters are also well portrayed in this, if a little jumbled up because I don't beleive it uses the same canonical sequence of events.The art style in this game really captures the style of the comics, but in its own unique manner. I did see a few graphical issues while playing, but nothing major. Telltale also did a good job at converting the setting of the comics into a 3D environment, as well as continuing the style in adding new locations.The soundtrack in this game is brilliant. It does a good job at adding ambiance to the story, as well as the environments.I've only played the game once, but I do see a lot of replayability in the future, as there are plenty of choices that could affect the outcome of the entire story.Overall this game is well deserving of its awards, and definitely worth a buy if you want a game with a good story to it.
