Posted: December 13, 2014
												The Wolf Among Us is what happens when you mix "Who Framed Roger Rabbit" with fairy tales and a choose your own adventure book. It is actually the canonical prequal to the comic book series Fables. In it you play as Bigby "The Big Bad" Wolf. Bigby is the sheriff of Fabletown which is a small neighborhood within New York. It is where all the Fables were exiled to after they weren't allowed to be in their stories anymore (one too many direct to VHS Disney movies I'm guessing) and ended up in a "Mundie" (normal human) city.Story: I don't want to give away much about the story so i'll just say there was a murder and it is your jub to find out "who done it." Gameplay:If you have ever played Telltale's "The Walking Dead" you'll know exactly how this game plays. In short TWAU is a gameplay-light story-heavy choose your own adventure book. That is not a bad thing by any means, but for many people that could be a turn off. There are almost no puzzle elements and the few that there are I would not even call puzzles. Overall:TWAU is a great game. The game's first episode starts out very strong, but the length and impact of each episode lowers as the story progresses. The characters are great, the QTE's are manageable, Bigby's chest hair is highly strokeable, and the voice acting is top-notch. If you have enjoyed a Telltale game before you'll love this.Final score:Four dancing werewolves out of three Japanese sweet fish cakes.[cdn.justonecookbook.com]

Posted: December 2, 2013
												My first exposure to a Telltale game was The Walking Dead, which I thoroughly enjoyed despite how depressing the story was.  This wasn't the fault of the game itself, mind you, but rather just a natural fact of any zombie story worth its weight in brains.  I expected nothing less.  When I picked up The Wolf Among Us, I was skeptical.  I didn't think that another story could exceed or even live up to what Telltale did with TWD.  I didn't think there was another fictional universe that Telltale could use to create a compelling, story-driven game with so much emotional punch.  I was wrong, and I'm comfortable admitting as much after playing only the first chapter.  The first thing about this game that stood out as exceptional was the visual style.  It's brilliant to look at, and you're drawn into this fictional universe from the beginning.  It's dark and brooding with high contrasts of colors that remind you that you're in what is essentially a fairy tale.  I've always been a fan of graphics that look amazing, but aren't hyper-realistic.  I loved the style of Borderlands and Borderlands 2 with their faux cel-shaded graphics.  Same with the game XIII.  Telltale's TWD had a great visual style as well, but it was nothing like this.  It's like a comic book that's come to life before your eyes without it turning into a cartoon.  The biggest draw of this game is the story.  First off, the entire premise of Fables is wonderful.  I was completely ignorant of the comic book series before I heard about this game, and I've since read a bit of it to edify myself on the lore and backstory of the characters.  I love the idea of dropping fairy tale characters into a modern New York City, and Telltale does an exceptional job of portraying this in the game.  There are many winks and nods to the source material while the game tells its own, standalone story.  I was pulled into the plot almost immediately, and by the end of the first chapter I was left with my mouth hanging agape, my mind racing with what-ifs, and most importantly wanting MORE.  The gameplay is standard Telltale tropes with some new ideas thrown in.  Meaningful decisions, quick-time dialogue and actions, and point-and-click exploration are all here.  These things would make for a boring game otherwise, but with the exceptional story you're never bored.  Adventure games are an interesting genre in this regard.  Some gamers who prefer more interaction in their games may not understand how a game like this can be exciting.  It is in the same way a good book is exciting, with an interesting story filled with great character interaction and unexpected plot twists.  Without these, the game would fail.  Telltale show off their story-telling chops here.TWAU is an exciting story that has a unique premise, interesting characters, and a main story that will make you want to play the entire chapter in one sitting because you just HAVE to find out what's going to happen next.  I think if Telltale adds some more interesting, neutral characters for Bigby to interact with in the next episode, the game will be even better.  If you're a fan of adventure games, you can't go wrong with this one, especially if you appreciate a good "whodunit" mystery set in a gritty, noir-filled world.

												Extremely entertaining, thus said, this is not a game... It is a story that has been "gamified", meaning that, it has interactive momments, but it is mainly just an animated series.The story is a completely different take on classic fables. Snow white, beauty and the beast, big bad wolf (what you play as), etc. They now live in the real world, with real problems...First of all, for those expecting action, there isnt much. About mechanics and what you can do? Well, you pick frases and actions everynow and then, that sometimes affects the storyline but usually just affects the outcome of the conversation... slightly...  What i should point out, is that this action/words choice, is not like bioware games. It definetly doesn't change the game as much, but it will make you think more.The choices here are emotional, it is not about the item you want or how you want to behave, but more about how you react emotionally. They feel important and heavier. Mainly because this game is a drama and there is a time to pick your choice, so that it feels like an actual conversation. Wierdly enough, you will feel realism here, eventhough its cartoonish and 105% fiction.It is a refreshing and original experience that earned TellTale their name and fame. Imo the best game they have, since it  works ontop of classic children fables while bringing a police/drama theme. Will "magically" distort your reality a few times, making you react in ways you would and wouldn't...

Posted: July 24, 2015
 The Wolf Among Us was one of the best games of 2014, and arguabely stands as Telltale's best game to date. I was first cautious to purchase this game. It was based on a source material that I knew nothing about, and seemingly featured fantastical themes which weren't really my 'thing' - werewolves, fairytales and the like. However, I took the plunge when episode five was released and I didn't look back.The Wolf Among Us is sleek, atmospheric, and out-right dark in places. Based on the comic  Fables , you play as Bigby wolf,  the  big bad wolf, sheriff and protector of Fabletown, a community of 'fables' and mythical creatures in New York after their banishment from their own world. A murder has occured, and you must put the pieces of the puzzle together to find the culprit. Without spoiling any more, The Wolf Among Us grows with every episode, the stakes become higher as Bigby uncovers more than he could have imagined from a single murder case, until the intense finale of episode five. The story is superbly written, the characters interesting and well developed - some of which you become very attached to. The environments are extemely atmospheric, and the music compliments them very well (the soundtrack is  amazing! ). The puzzels are fun, although not too challenging, and as with most Telltale titles take a back seat in favour of branching dialogue. All combat is QTE, which is done alright with this game, but I know many people get annoyed with these controls - point and click isn't for everyone! Overall it is a fantastic adventure game worth paying for, in my opinion level with Walking Dead Season 1. Tentitive to purchase it primarily, but now I am a fully-fledged fan of the game.  This is worth buying at full price - especially if you loved The Walking Dead. You will love this too!  One final word on people's biggest moan about Telltale: choices. "Your choices don't matter...they don't affect the plot...it's all an illusion" is what is said all of the time in comments. While it is true they don't affect the plot in drastic ways, they affect two things: the protagonist, and the player. The protagonists in all Telltale games are shaped by your choices. Will Lee be a hopeful person, and try and teach Clementine to hold onto the old ways of civility? Or will he adapt, and teach her survival at any cost. Similarly Bigby can try and prove himself to be a caring and decent sheriff, or live up to his name as the big bad wolf. Finally the player is shaped by the choices: your perception of the game/story will change depending on what you pick, how you feel about other characters, how you feel about yourself, and, for me anyway, they stick with me and undoubtedly change my mindset for the rest of the game. So yes, the choices do have value, just not really plot-wise, which seems to be the only thing which matters to some people.

												First off this is more of an interactive storybook than a real game. That said, the story is extremely compelling, the art style beautiful, and the characters complex and believable. The gameplay itself goes by really quickly so make good use of that pause button or you'll feel rushed and make mistakes. Most of the game is looking for and putting clues together, and most games either make the clues so easy to work with that you feel like a coddled child, or so difficult to work with that you get frustrated and give up and look everything up on a wiki. This game though does the clues PERFECTLY, and you will really feel a sense of accomplishment when you put things together. You will also feel very in control of the story, even when you're not. The choices you get to make as Bigby Wolf really let you define his character. Are you a good man with a terrible past, trying to redeem yourself? Are you simply a law-enforcer, tired of fighting? Posted: February 5, 2016
												Pros:-Bigby Wolf is a fun character to play as. You can play him in many clear ways and even combine different paths you can take.-The world of Fables is fascinating because you are familiar with many of the characters in this game already, but not in the way this world represents them, which really kept me engaged. -Being a badass investigator solving a murder mystery in a world styled like a comic book is something I've never experienced in a game before and this game does an amazing job of combining all these elements into one. -The way the game quickly switched between dialogue to action sequences was fantastic and it kept me on the edge of my seat. Cons:-The consequences and choices always seem pretty dire in the heat of the moment, but sometimes the results are the same regardless of your path. -The typical frame rate problems between loading screens (Telltale Games are kinda known for this) -The ending of the game left too many questions unanswered. It kinda begs for a Season 2. So if there isn't a Season 2, this game really didn't get a proper ending. Overall:As far as Telltale Games goes, The Wolf Among Us is my all time favorite. I really fell in love with how these fairy tale characters were put into a setting that modernized them and changed my way of how I thought of them. Telltale did a great job of combining the murder mystery LA Noire feel with the style of a comic book, which bring together a fantastic looking game. You really do feel like Bigby Wolf trying he's best to solve the murder mystery and also trying to obtain acceptance from the other Fables. So will you be the good cop or the bad cop?Rating: 9/10

Posted: July 10, 2014
												Whether or not you like this game is going to boil down to one simple question: How much are you willing to pay for quality story writing?  Because at its core, that's what Telltale Games is offering.  Without a doubt, this is a truly excellent interactive story which is a hell of a blast from beginning to end.  I can't emphasize enough that the story is really, really good, a bright star in a sea of darkness that is AAA story writing.But (and this is where people will chew me out): That's all there is, a great story.  And for some people, that's enough.  But this sort of game is not for everyone.The game is composed entirely of walk-around segments where you look for clues that are relatively easy to find, and QTE segments which are relatively easy to beat.  I've never been a great detective, but when the game makes it as easy as these ones do, I don't feel like I need to be all that smart to figure out what's going on.  I'm also a terrible button masher and I'm even worse at QTEs, and I still beat every QTE sequence with very little struggle to speak of, and never once died.  It is an outright challenge just to die in this game.There is also relatively little in terms of "length" in this game.  As of this post, I have logged about 16 hours.  Of those, perhaps 10 were honest gameplay.  The rest were either moments when I left the computer running while doing errands, was forced to reload segments due to dialogue bugs, or was purposely rewinding to finish my Book of Fables achievements.  The game will not keep you playing for very long, unless you don't mind going through the same story multiple times even after you know the ending.And that would be less of a problem if there were replay value, but there is effectively none to speak of.  Telltale's tagline that "your choices matter" doesn't extend nearly as far as you'd like it to.  Certainly, there are actions, and there are consequences, but they are not as significant as the game makes them appear.  There are NPCs you can save, but their role is relatively minor from that point on.  There are parts where you can be a total prick (I was) and go around mauling and killing, and it'll result in only minor changes to a few lines of dialogue here and there.  There are locations that you can choose from, but oftentimes you'll end up visiting both locations anyways, and the only "changes" will be minor ones.  The story is effectively set in stone and there's pretty much nothing you can do to change its course.  The sole reason to go back and replay any segments is to unlock alternate Book of Fables entries, which I did on a few occasions.Now I should reiterate what I said earlier.  This is not a bad game.  The story is excellent, and for what it's worth, I had fun while playing it.  I would even go so far as to say that, for the $12.50 I paid for it, this game effectively gave me my money's worth.  So I want to make that perfectly clear before people get on my case.But with that said....this sort of game is very polarizing in the gaming community for a reason, and I can't in good conscience tell all my friends that this is a "must-buy" game, because it isn't.  It's a fantastic story, but as a game, it has weaknesses that will turn some people off.  This game is great for people who want a great story experience with minimal, very forgiving gameplay, and obviously for fans of any previous Telltale game.  This game is definitely not for people who don't care much for story, or for people who want serious and/or less forgiving gameplay, or for people who (in general) buy a game expecting countless hours of gameplay.The best summary I can give is this: Buying this game, as with all Telltale games, is effectively like purchasing a book with some gameplay attached to it, where the only real "replay value" is in reading the story again.  And if that's okay with you, this is definitely a worthy pickup at pretty much any price.  If it's not, this is probably not the title for you.

Posted: December 29, 2014
												The Wolf Among Us is another good narrative by Telltale, let down by a rather low playtime, even compared to their previous effort, The Walking Dead Season 1. The game only takes 6-8 hours to play through, and there's not a whole lot of replayability; though there are alternate scenes and locations that can occur, at the very least. It's well-written and well-made, as usual, and it's an enjoyable experience, but a rather brief one. I don't recommend it at full price, but on sale it's certainly worth a look.A few downsides; the swearing and gore felt a bit excessive at times, for sure. Just 'cause you have an M rating doesn't mean you need to flaunt it all the time. Again, the choices don't matter particularly much, either, and there's no challenge to be had as well; I never died or failed in any way once throughout the entire game, which certainly wasn't the case for TWD Season 1. These are only minor gripes overall, though, I still enjoyed this for the 75% off price I paid for it.

Posted: July 10, 2014
												Whether or not you like this game is going to boil down to one simple question: How much are you willing to pay for quality story writing?  Because at its core, that's what Telltale Games is offering.  Without a doubt, this is a truly excellent interactive story which is a hell of a blast from beginning to end.  I can't emphasize enough that the story is really, really good, a bright star in a sea of darkness that is AAA story writing.But (and this is where people will chew me out): That's all there is, a great story.  And for some people, that's enough.  But this sort of game is not for everyone.The game is composed entirely of walk-around segments where you look for clues that are relatively easy to find, and QTE segments which are relatively easy to beat.  I've never been a great detective, but when the game makes it as easy as these ones do, I don't feel like I need to be all that smart to figure out what's going on.  I'm also a terrible button masher and I'm even worse at QTEs, and I still beat every QTE sequence with very little struggle to speak of, and never once died.  It is an outright challenge just to die in this game.There is also relatively little in terms of "length" in this game.  As of this post, I have logged about 16 hours.  Of those, perhaps 10 were honest gameplay.  The rest were either moments when I left the computer running while doing errands, was forced to reload segments due to dialogue bugs, or was purposely rewinding to finish my Book of Fables achievements.  The game will not keep you playing for very long, unless you don't mind going through the same story multiple times even after you know the ending.And that would be less of a problem if there were replay value, but there is effectively none to speak of.  Telltale's tagline that "your choices matter" doesn't extend nearly as far as you'd like it to.  Certainly, there are actions, and there are consequences, but they are not as significant as the game makes them appear.  There are NPCs you can save, but their role is relatively minor from that point on.  There are parts where you can be a total prick (I was) and go around mauling and killing, and it'll result in only minor changes to a few lines of dialogue here and there.  There are locations that you can choose from, but oftentimes you'll end up visiting both locations anyways, and the only "changes" will be minor ones.  The story is effectively set in stone and there's pretty much nothing you can do to change its course.  The sole reason to go back and replay any segments is to unlock alternate Book of Fables entries, which I did on a few occasions.Now I should reiterate what I said earlier.  This is not a bad game.  The story is excellent, and for what it's worth, I had fun while playing it.  I would even go so far as to say that, for the $12.50 I paid for it, this game effectively gave me my money's worth.  So I want to make that perfectly clear before people get on my case.But with that said....this sort of game is very polarizing in the gaming community for a reason, and I can't in good conscience tell all my friends that this is a "must-buy" game, because it isn't.  It's a fantastic story, but as a game, it has weaknesses that will turn some people off.  This game is great for people who want a great story experience with minimal, very forgiving gameplay, and obviously for fans of any previous Telltale game.  This game is definitely not for people who don't care much for story, or for people who want serious and/or less forgiving gameplay, or for people who (in general) buy a game expecting countless hours of gameplay.The best summary I can give is this: Buying this game, as with all Telltale games, is effectively like purchasing a book with some gameplay attached to it, where the only real "replay value" is in reading the story again.  And if that's okay with you, this is definitely a worthy pickup at pretty much any price.  If it's not, this is probably not the title for you.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												The Wolf Amoung Us is a game by Telltale games where you can make your own decisions which will affects later episodes,Story:I will only mention the first episode story in a nutshell, most characters are all from fairytales stories like Snow White, Beauty and the Beast, Red Riding Hood and many more, Bigby (AKA Big Bad Wolf) is the Sheriff of Fabletown and have to protects all other Fables (Fairytale stories characters) from each other.*SPOILERS ALERT*The story begins as Bigby in a taxi cab on his way to Toad's apartment to help him, once arrived there was a lot of noise caused from the second floor, Bigby discovers that the Woodsman started attacking a women (with anger as she does not remember him as a hero from the Red Riding Hood) Bigby stops the Woodsman and attacked him, endding while jumping out from a 2nd Story window and landing on Toad's car, Bigby then is still attacked and being suffocated while the women grabbed his axe and hit him on the back of his head, after a little conversation Bigby then returns to his appartment and have a little chat with Colin before going to sleep, later Snow hurried to Bigby to show a chopped off head of the women (who was in Toad's appartment earlier) in the appartment's doorstep (you can decide whether to investigate or not), you will then investigate who she was, she is discovered to be Faith from the story Donkeyskin and then visit her husband Lawerence, but a call is recieved from Toad asking for help, this when to decide who to go to first, the story will change depending on who you visit first, the story ends in the Trip Trap Bar and having a small conversation with the Woodsman, but then attacked by Gren, after the battle Dee will enter and you will have a choice to either arrest the Woodsman or Dee (who was in Lawerence's home) and then find another murder was commited and this time Snow's head was on the doorstep.*SPOILERS END HERE*Gameplay:Playing the game is very simple, you move Bigby with WASD (Up, Left, Down, Right respectivly) and use the mouse to interact with things and people, like picking up evidence, talking to people, opening doors, etc., but during fights it consists of Quicktime events like tapping the Q button rapidly, pressing W or A or S or D to avoid things when shown and land hits on your opponent you will need to positionate the mouse cursor on the location shown required to attack him. (Please note you can't move freely and land your own hits, the game will show you what you buttons or clicks you need to perform in order to complete and win the fight)Looks/Soundtrack:If you played the walking dead you will notice it looks similar, it also looks similar as the art of Marvel comic books, everything looks great, the 3D models are great, backgrounds are also great, there nothing more to say, while the Soundtrack there is not much to listen to however the voices are very clear with subtitles, and the background noises are all fine.Length:The length of each episode should be about 30 to 60 minutes, but once you finish an episode, you will end up starting a new save file with diffrent decisions to amaze yourself with all the diffrences occuring in later episodes.

												When I first heard of this game from a friend, I was like "Meh, maybe I'll check it out." A month later, my friend was still bothering me about it, so I watched the first episode of it via YouTube. In the first few minutes, I was absorbed. The game already had a good developing story line, and I LOVED the characters. At that one moment, I decided to give TTG all my money and buy The Wolf Among Us not only for one system, but for two (my Xbox 360 and my Steam). And now that the season is over, I can assure you all that this game is a work of art, and while I also thoroughly enjoyed the Walking Dead Series and S2 (Still currently enjoying) I can say that The Wolf Among Us definetley had a stronger feeling to it. I was the law, but I didn't get free donuts or anything. I got mean glares, and I got in trouble (frequently). I got to play the good guy, who wasn't popular or loved, but hated. I was the Big Bad Wolf, the sherriff, yet I still had life hard for me. And there was so much drama and suspense sometimes that the Wolf had to make descisions that would ruin him and any others. This really pulled me in, having a position so powerful and matching it with a character who doesn't always play by the rules and still had the ability to "Lose."The Wolf Among Us is for people who enjoy a good mystery, action, and  suspense. So yea, I highly recommend it, and you should all give TTG all of your money for making such a masterpiece like this. Bravo, TTG, Bravo.

												I've never read the Fables comics that Wolf Among Us is based on, but I really enjoyed Telltale's previous adventure game The Walking Dead, so I was pretty confident that I would like this game too and that absolutely turned out to be correct.Wolf Among Us is set in Fabletown, where famous fairy tale characters such as Beauty and the Beast and Snow White live in secret amongst normal Humans. The player takes control of Sherriff Bigby Wolf (the Big Bad Wolf), whose job is to make sure the Fables follow the law.The excellent main story revolves around a murder investigation, while also adding details to how these Fables live their lives day to day. The characters are very well written with complex personalities, and have fantastic voice acting.Gameplay is mostly about dialogue, choosing how Bigby should respond during conversations with the other Fables. You can also make some decisions about how to proceed with the investigation, and your choices can influence how the story plays out. There are a few small crime scenes where you can walk around and examine clues, then use what you learned in future conversations. And there are some fights and chases that are controlled by QTEs, but these are quite forgiving, most of the time missing a button press just makes you progress in a different way. I never ended up in a failure state that required me reload and try again.Controls are not rebindable and I don't like wasd, so I played with an Xbox 360 controller instead, which worked fine. I didn't encounter any bugs, there were a couple of times that I was worried I had suffered a crash, but it just seems that sometimes loading of the next scene can be a bit slow.If you like a good story, I definitely recommend Wolf Among Us.

												I was reluctant to type up a review before the release of episode 5 because I thought they might screw up in the end, but it certainly wasn't that disappointing - quite the opposite, really. Not to mention the very well done action sequences and an absolutely amazing soundtrack.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												(9.5/10)I really was not sure what to expect out of this game.  I was not familair with the 'fables' source material, and enjoyed, but did not necessarily all-out love the prior telltale outings (sam & max, walking dead, etc).Well... 15 minutes in I pretty much was hooked.  The characters feel very well realized, and I was emotionally bound up in the story more deeply than I've been with a game in years.  The quicktime events are mildly frustrating, as they pretty much always will be in games, but this is no "Tomb Raider" and you can miss a few of those triggers now and again without it ruining the game for you.  The "silence is always an option" actually had me sometimes seriously sit back and wait, as the prepared responses simply didn't feel right, and generally the non action was more the action I felt was right and fit well.Certainly very highly reccomended on many levels for all who love adventure games, noir in general, and fables or other 'darker' ediger modern fairy tale stuff in general.  I dare you to not just play it all the way through... assuming you have the time of course.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												First off this is more of an interactive storybook than a real game. That said, the story is extremely compelling, the art style beautiful, and the characters complex and believable. The gameplay itself goes by really quickly so make good use of that pause button or you'll feel rushed and make mistakes. Most of the game is looking for and putting clues together, and most games either make the clues so easy to work with that you feel like a coddled child, or so difficult to work with that you get frustrated and give up and look everything up on a wiki. This game though does the clues PERFECTLY, and you will really feel a sense of accomplishment when you put things together. You will also feel very in control of the story, even when you're not. The choices you get to make as Bigby Wolf really let you define his character. Are you a good man with a terrible past, trying to redeem yourself? Are you simply a law-enforcer, tired of fighting?  Or are you still just 'The Big Bad Wolf'?

Posted: July 11, 2014
												The Wolf Among us Is a story Driven point and click game Made by Telltale Games. The game puts you in the shoes of the famous fairy tale character The big bad wolf  Known as  bIgby Wolf a sherrif of fabletown Full of fairy tale legends who have left the old world  and have come to Our world  trying to fit in with the mundys (Humans) disguised to look like them. Sheffif bigby leaving his history behind trys to become a better person by being the law. The story puts you in a murder mystery case you and Snow white are trying to solve with shocking revelations that you uncover along the way and well executed action scenes with quick time events that are done well. The game from start to finish is a fantastic game with a story that has you so interested to find out what happens next and the shocking cliff hangers just force you to play the next episode for sure.This is along with great characters that you will meet and that you will recognise from a story such as Snow white, one of the 3 little pigs, the woodsman, Toad and many more but how you interact with them is up to you. You can be the meanest by choosing all the bad choices that will all in some way have an outcome that might effect you in some way. Or you can try and be the nice guy trying to not allways be the d*ck that the whole of fabletown know you as but even sometimes you have to be that guy to get your answer's out of people whether thats intimidating characters or just plain beating them up. This game has got beautifull cell shaded graphics that bring the comic book style to it which looks great with the vibrant stand out colors. While playing episode after episode of the game i couldnt help but notice that the soundtrack is awesome and comes in at the right times in the game at appropriate times in scenes. In the game their were some parts with interaction with characters that i felt that wasnt needed and just felt pointless some episodes are weaker than overs. Also when you are looking for clues you have a load of interactions with clues and objects but if you interact with a certain clue it will just move you on and not letting you fully explore what it has to offer you. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Overall The wolf among us as a whole is well written                                                                  well voice acted                                                                  well animated                                                                  A immersive story to be played                                                                 with good characters I recomend to all Definitely

Posted: February 5, 2016
												Pros:-Bigby Wolf is a fun character to play as. You can play him in many clear ways and even combine different paths you can take.-The world of Fables is fascinating because you are familiar with many of the characters in this game already, but not in the way this world represents them, which really kept me engaged. -Being a badass investigator solving a murder mystery in a world styled like a comic book is something I've never experienced in a game before and this game does an amazing job of combining all these elements into one. -The way the game quickly switched between dialogue to action sequences was fantastic and it kept me on the edge of my seat. Cons:-The consequences and choices always seem pretty dire in the heat of the moment, but sometimes the results are the same regardless of your path. -The typical frame rate problems between loading screens (Telltale Games are kinda known for this) -The ending of the game left too many questions unanswered. It kinda begs for a Season 2. So if there isn't a Season 2, this game really didn't get a proper ending. Overall:As far as Telltale Games goes, The Wolf Among Us is my all time favorite. I really fell in love with how these fairy tale characters were put into a setting that modernized them and changed my way of how I thought of them. Telltale did a great job of combining the murder mystery LA Noire feel with the style of a comic book, which bring together a fantastic looking game. You really do feel like Bigby Wolf trying he's best to solve the murder mystery and also trying to obtain acceptance from the other Fables. So will you be the good cop or the bad cop?Rating: 9/10

Posted: July 9, 2014
												TellTale does it again!I just finished the entire game, all five episodes although I haven't gone back just yet to see about other choices and how it can impact the game, but I can say right now that Wolf Among Us is just as engaging as the Walking Dead games, something that I am truly impressed with.The gameplay is a point and click adventure, streamlined for casual players. Clickable items are shown with orbs, and most things to discover really aren't too far out of reach of newer players of the genre. The game also has a mode where you can turn that off if you want a challenge, but on your second playthrough you most likely remember where everything is, so if you want to go with this option, I'd do it on your first playthrough.A lot of really cool characters, top notch voice acting, and some genuinely intense moments (although I've found that they are far more intense in the Walking Dead games by Tell Tale which I would also really recommend checking out). The graphics, while not going to be something that take advantage of your four SLI Titans, are bright, colorful and undeniably charming. They look like they popped out of a comic book.I'd recommend it.

Posted: August 8, 2016
												Adventure game based on a line of graphic novels named "Fables", where characters from old fairy tales have come to live in human society. It's typical Telltale-style gaming here, so no surprises about the mechanics or playstyle. I felt the source material was treated quite well which is great - I ended up marathoning the game and it did not leave me disappointed. It was certainly able to hold my attention. A few of the twists were telegraphed well enough that I caught them, but for the most part I didn't mind. A sequel would be great since I'm left wanting more, luckily it was based on those graphic novels so I can just go grab a few of them to get my fix. The only regret I have for this game is that I didn't play it back when I bought it, as it was certainly worth the playtime I put in.

The gameplay itself is simple point & click, but the story and characters are so gripping that you are drawn in right from the start.  In just a couple of hours, the game created a world and characters that I cared about (I haven't read the comics that this game is based upon, though after playing episode 1, I may have to go out and buy them); by the end of the first episode, I've already become invested in these characters and cannot wait for the next episode to be released!  The game also offers you the ability to make choices which impact the story (and often there are no clear right or wrong choices) - so the game seems to have great replayability value.  The art style is amazing, the music fits the theme, and the voice acting is well done.

Posted: December 15, 2013
												I highly recommended this game. The beautiful and vibrate cartoonish cell shading art style really matches the grim story of the Fables within Fabletown. The story thus far is about The Big Bad Wolf, Mr. Bigsby, following the recent murders in Fabletown. So much like The Walking Dead game (both are made by Tale Tell Games) is episode based and choices made within the game will reflect throughout the game. Even in the first episode your choices do make significant changes within the game. The in game fight/decision system is great. It’s much better than The Walking Dead in game fight/decision system. I do feel the investigation aspect of the game is lacking and maybe it’s the first episode. I feel that The Walking Dead is better in that area. Overall that game is great. The story, gameplay, art style and overall feel of the game work very well. Overall: 9/10 -- Not sure it’s worth $30 currently (only one episode) but definitely if it is on sale.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												I love adventure games, and I love Western-style comic books and graphic novels. This is an adventure game based on a comic book series written by one of the principal writer's of Image Comics, 'The Walking Dead' series. The adaptation for television is now a blockbuster tv show. The gist of the 'Wolf Among Us', series is that Fables have been forced to update themselves in NYC, and you are the Big Bad Wolf, and Fabletown's Sheriff. There has been a murder in Fabletown, and as Sheriff you have to play the gumshoe and solve the case. Simple gameplay, with lots of story. Finally, your decisions, wise or otherwise, have a large effect on the results of the game. If you like the genre of this game, then its well worth the try.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												The Wolf Among Us (Episode 1) is the latest game from Telltale Games and the first of a new series. Based on DC Vertigo's "Fables" comic series, you play the role of Bigby Wolf (formerly the Big Bad Wolf of Little Red Riding Hood fame) and now the sheriff of Fabletown - a hidden world of fable characters in New York City. The last Telltale series I played was "Sam & Max", so I wasn't expecting the more "graphic novel" approach to the game. There are sections of the game which play more like traditional point-n-click adventures, but with all the potential hotspots in the area highlighted for you, it's less about hunting for things on screen and more about clicking on everything to unlock more of the story. The story is an extremely violent affair dealing with a murder in Fabletown. This is not a game for kids. The language is bad, lots of cursing, and the violence is pretty violent. The characters, voice acting and art are all absolutely first rate. The game itself is fun, but pretty easy. Even the action sequences, which involve hitting keys quickly in order to cause actions or avoid harm, are pleasantly forgiving. The game is more about choices than action, however. The game tells you when you've made a choice which will have lasting impact on the game. One downside is that the episode is on the short side. I played it from start to finish, including the tutorial, in under 2 hours. The ending came abruptly and left me sitting at the keyboard wondering what to do next. The game provides some feedback at the end of the episode about how your choices compare to other players of the game (38% of players make the same choice you did, for example). It's an interesting statistic, and from a psychology standpoint, it would be really cool to see more stats and more detail, but I suppose there's a limit to what they can show you without making it boring or spoiling future episodes. It's a great story so far. I found myself lost in it for the 2 hours it took to complete. If you can pick it up on sale, I recommend that - it makes the shortness more palletable. I know there will be more episodes, but if they are all roughly the same length, we're only talking about 10 hours or so gameplay for the season. That seems low for the full price cost of the game - no matter how good the production values are. I highly recommend The Wolf Among Us, at any price, but with the holiday sale going on, there's no reason not to get it if you can score the discount.

Posted: March 14, 2014
												I just finished Episode 1 ... this game definitely has the same feel as The Walking Dead, but it is also different. It is certainly more action packed, for one thing. I would even say that it is more violent, which may be hard to believe at first. In The Walking Dead, you mostly shoot people. With a gun, you have more distance -- both physically and emotionally -- between you and the person you kill. But, in The Wolf Among Us you have to brutally beat people up, with your bare hands. It is a much more visceral experience. I liked it. There were times when Snow's dialogue disrupted the immersion of the player, especially when it was painfully obvious that the developers were using her to basically tell you what to do. Other than that, I don't really have any complaints. The art style is vibrant yet edgy at the same time. There are a host of interesting and complicated characters. It's just a great game so far. i'm looking forward to playing Episode 2 and the remaining episodes when they are released.

												I didn't expect to, but I really liked this game!  The dialogue and voice-acting were phenomenal.  The artwork made the whole game seem like I was participating in a living graphic novel. Also, I wished I could have dialed up the difficulty as I sometimes felt the game was handing me a easy win.9/10 Excellent storytelling!

Posted: July 22, 2014
												The Tell Tale games are great when you just don't have the energy for other games.  They are like interactive movies that both enterain and engage.  I find the company's games perfect for a quiet night in where I can stuff my fae with food and still be able to easily engage in a game (I am not very good at multitasking food and games!).  The Wolf Among Us is based in the universe of the Fables comic book series.  It felt very true to the series for those who are big fans.  The first season surrounds a mysterious murder of a Fabletown inhabitant that the main character, Bigby Wolf (The Big Bad Wolf) encounters very early in the story.  There is mystery, murder, magic, and fantasy as well as some good old fashioned gore.  There are several plot twists that are quite catching.I personally look forward to another season of this series.  I have enjoyed it just as much as The Walking Dead.  It's a different genre but the story gets better and better as you go.  It's been years since I really have enjoyed point-click story games.  Tell Tale Games has done a great job with everything I have played of theirs so far.  Even if it is not my cup of tea, I have picked up their games and always found myself enjoying the story.  I hope you will give this one a chance.  You may fight yourself pleasantly surprised by the darkness twisted into our childhood tales.

												Telltale graced our lives with some amazing games in the past and this is no exception. Walking Dead was an amazing story that we had the chance to live through as we suffered a multitude of consequences for our decisions. The Wolf Among Us has upped the ante and breathed new life into the comics for the gamers lucky enough to play through the world of Fables. I admit that I did love Walking Dead Season 1, but TWAU blew me away. The maturity of the creators after their journey into the world of zombies has increased exponentially and it shows. I have always had an interest in zombies and read Walking Dead before ever playing the first Telltale Games "story", but with Fables I've only been briefly introduced and now yearn to not only collect the graphic novels but also to cross my fingers that Telltale continues to put out such masterpieces of storytelling (including another Fables storyline) because I'm hooked.Honestly, it blows my mind how interested I am in this style of gaming/storytelling. I've loved comics since a young age, but my gaming preferences have always been geared toward RPG or FPS-style action. I grew up playing Wolfenstein and Final Fantasy so those two genres always keept me with an itchy trigger finger and a brain thirsty to digest the epic stories and adventures that took all too many hours of rest away from my youth. Yet here I sit after playing through my second Telltale game and I feel like I've found a new love in this style of gameplay. It might not be the best for action-oriented gamers, but for those of you who may enjoy a good story and don't mind occasionally sitting back and not taking much action then THIS is the game to play.Without a doubt I would recommend this game to anyone who even remotely wants to live in the comics. Anyone who has ever read through plenty of choose-your-own-adventure books, loves to be a part of a good story and deal with the consequences, or just wants a relaxing game to play through between bouts of COD or whatever the kids may play these days. Give it a shot. After all, I want to see my RPG/FPS/story-telling come to life in the Borderlands game that Telltale is supposed to hand deliver to me (at least I can dream) and this is the way to help fund them to make more beautiful games.

Posted: October 23, 2015
												I don't usually write reviews for games, but I enjoyed this one so much that I really want to share how awesome it is. I won't get super into detail, but basically; if you ever wonder whether or not you should play this, play it. The graphics are beautiful, it feels like you're literally interacting with a comic book, and the noir-style storytelling is so satisfying to watch and play with. The characters, from the original comic and the new ones, are so well-written. The plot is fantastic, had me on the edge of my seat the whole time I was playing. I'm ashamed it took me this long to get around to playing through it.My new favorite Telltale game! If you love mysteries, comics, fairytales or noir stories, you'll love it too!

												When I first heard of this game from a friend, I was like "Meh, maybe I'll check it out." A month later, my friend was still bothering me about it, so I watched the first episode of it via YouTube. In the first few minutes, I was absorbed. The game already had a good developing story line, and I LOVED the characters. At that one moment, I decided to give TTG all my money and buy The Wolf Among Us not only for one system, but for two (my Xbox 360 and my Steam). And now that the season is over, I can assure you all that this game is a work of art, and while I also thoroughly enjoyed the Walking Dead Series and S2 (Still currently enjoying) I can say that The Wolf Among Us definetley had a stronger feeling to it. I was the law, but I didn't get free donuts or anything. I got mean glares, and I got in trouble (frequently). I got to play the good guy, who wasn't popular or loved, but hated. I was the Big Bad Wolf, the sherriff, yet I still had life hard for me. And there was so much drama and suspense sometimes that the Wolf had to make descisions that would ruin him and any others. This really pulled me in, having a position so powerful and matching it with a character who doesn't always play by the rules and still had the ability to "Lose."The Wolf Among Us is for people who enjoy a good mystery, action, and  suspense. So yea, I highly recommend it, and you should all give TTG all of your money for making such a masterpiece like this. Bravo, TTG, Bravo.

Posted: July 10, 2014
 The Wolf Among Us  A Film Noir Drama, that loudly goes nowhere.. (I realise that this will easily be the most controversial piece that i have ever written, but you cannot archieve fame/notoriety without being a bit of a tosser.)Well, that subtext kinda reveals my point without explaining. I have a right tonne of stuff to nitpick.. However, i'm not going to fight hyperactive fanboys over this point. Instead of fighting, i'm just going to point out the problems in this particular series. Whilst attempting to cut out all the possible spoilers and trying to tie everything in to a cohesive critique..( All whilst suffering from bronchitis and tanking painkillers. ) The review has a lot of references to the Graphic novel series, so unless you have read them. Please refrain from posting bad arguments. The game starts in a way that i find very solid, like in the graphic novels. (Yes, i have now read all the books.) But unlike the novels, the game seems to have a rather obvious pacing problem. Maybe due to the episodic nature, but before you nag about it being the same in the novels. The novels had a very clear notion of what is happening, having an isolated short story in each issue and having small hints for what might happen next.The game attempts this storytelling method, but manages to muck it up slightly.. Or moderately. This is the part where i turn very biased, so if you excuse me for a minute...TellTale has a reputation of making some very good episodic titles, one of my personal favourites being the Sam & Max series. But no matter how well you manage to create a story and setting for the characters in question, there are always some lurches that manage to appear. Sam & Max fans know what i'm talking about here.. That certain episode that was listed as "A waste of time" even by Sam & Max themselves. These lurches appear usually when you have "Too many irons in the furnace". If i managed to translate that correctly, or if that metaphor didn't work. Lets just say "Having too big of a sip from an icy slushie and getting a brainfreeze". Having too much stuff that you can actually manage. Causing everything they do, a little half-baked. And by that i mean; A raw slob of dough that you kept in the oven for only 15-Minutes and though it was properly cooked. Wow! My metaphors are terrible when i'm sick.. But back to review before i get distracted more...Like i was trying to explain, by my metaphorically deprived way; The game is not that good. I took some time to discuss this problem with one of my friends and we came to a conclusion that the pacing was off. Amongst other things..So the "friends video-game club discussion" that we had, came to a conclusion that the games pacing was along the lines of a badly edited TV-Programme. Starting in a solid way, then getting cut as everything got interesting and after that filling some time faffing about, then finally ending in a cliffhanger. Oh f*ck! i just spoiled the ending.And speaking of the ending, after spoiling the cilffhanger. Its one of those endings that gives closure to the story, but explains absolutely NOTHING. The game already had some holes in its plot like a colinder has for flour,  Why am i fixated on baking all of the sudden?  and none of those thing are even remotely explained during the ending. The rest is a bit of a spoiler, so i'l black it out for you..  The ending that is the one chatting up to Nerissa, explains nothing more than the things connected to Lily the first murder victim. Nerissa explains, that it was her who left the head in front of the Woodlands Building. Bridging in the missing pieces on how she died, but thats it.  So even with that ending, i felt confused and dazed. Since i felt, as i mentioned, that nothing was explained.And those are the problems i have with this particular series. I'm not going to copy-paste the usual, "Great visuals" "Marvellous atmosphere" And all the other faff. Since you know (if you have read any of my other reviews) i don't really give a damn about visual style.I just realised, that i really haven't been writing a review. Rather i have written a long line of nitpicking.. But even with being a nitpick, it still has a decent point and the point being: "The game had terrible pacing, some obvious plotholes and an ending that explains nothing." And i cannot do nothing else but to get annoyed at the fact that TellTale are going to attempt to explain the stuff in the second season, if there even will be one..But all my narking aside..The Wolf Among Us, is a quirky but enjoyable story set in the Fables universe. But i cannot really recommend it over the books, but i will recommend it as a spinoff title, even with its problems.Rating? i quess.. Thinking about it, as my painkiller buffed brain can cope.I think a reasonable B+ is in order.Reasons being: plotholes, pacing issues, the ending and TellTales time management.

Posted: October 19, 2015
												First of all I'd say this is more of a Visual Novel than a Point and Click adventure game. You don't need to hunt anything on the screen, everything is obviously highlighted. The gameplay is not at all about testing your power of observation and patience its all about making diaglogue choices under a time pressure. Which is the crux of telltale's style. Every dialogue tree comes with a timer, you have to pick something to say in that time or you say nothing. Which is a valid option and sometimes the "best" one.The story and atmosphere are great, if you like the whole hard boiled detective (sherriff in this case) theme. Not quite Noir and its not all dark and stormy nights but Bigby Wolf has it tough and he's even tougher.It'll take well under 10hrs to complete, but its worth the money. The TellTale niche of making VN's that use QTE (google it) combat to inject some action and adrenaline into proceedings works quite well. While its far from perfect, you will want to finish the story and you should probably take some satisfaction from being the Big Bad Wolf however you choose to play him.Highly recommend unless the idea read/watching a game instead of playing it is a huge turn off.

Posted: July 8, 2014
												If you liked The Walking Dead from the telltale studios you won't be dissapointed by the Wolf among us. If you also read the critically acclaimed Fables comics you will definitely love the Wolf among us. Point and Click adventures aren't that en vogue at the moment and probably will never be as in demand as they have been in their prime (Monkey Island, Day of the Tentacle, Broken Sword etc.)  but tWau definitely tries to revive the genre and seems to be succeeding so far. The story is dark and grasping and might even surprise an avid reader of the comics. Furthermore it has one of the most stylish protagonist you'll ever get to meet in an adventure game.  Not only is the voice acting supreme, but also his looks, be it transformed or normal. In addition he is very easy to identify with as you can feel his frustration and the urge to let it all go to hell and let the Big Bad Wolf out sometimes.Now for the bad parts:The gameplay can be a bit annoying sometimes as every fight is mostly just evading by pressing the right buttons at the right times, but it doesnt really matter if you get beaten bloody by opponents as the game will go on anyways. Furthermore the dialogs can be a bit repetative as every character has a certain angle: Bluebeard is a♥♥♥♥♥♥and needs to be constantly reminded of that fact, crane is a creep and needs to be constantly reminded of that fact, toad wont get glamoured and needs to be..........Nevertheless the Wolf among us is a very fine piece of software and well deserves all the positive receptions it gets at the moment. I can only strongly suggest that you buy this game, play this game and be very happy with this game.

Posted: September 26, 2014
												A truly fantastic experience unlike any other I have seen in a computer game. The storyline is honestly one of the best I have ever read/seen in any form of storytelling. Disguised as human beings, fairytale characters, referred to as 'Fables', live among us in New York City in the mid 1980's. Scraping to get by, these characters live in a world in which even their own government is unable to help them. The underworld of Fabletown seeks to take advantage of these innocent characters and it is up to Sheriff Bigby Wolf (known more famously as the Big Bad Wolf) to keep these characters safe. When the decapitated head of a Fable is found out the front of Bigby's apartment, a murder investigation begins that sees the player delving deeper and deeper into the world and sufferings of Fabletown.By Telltale Games, The Wolf Among Us is an 80's noir-murder mystery adventure game. More like an interactive movie than a computer game, the player takes on the role of the impatient Sheriff, discovering clues as well as questioning/interrogating characters to discover the killer of the murdered Fable. You decide how Bigby will respond when characters such as Snow White and Bloody Mary talk to him. These decisions have an effect on how the story plays out. Some effect your relationships with characters and some alter the overall story. This game perfectly contrasts the seemingly innocent fairytale stories that we all know and love, and places the characters from them in a truly dark, gritty, seedy and violent world. Telltale have created something that I am truly enthralled with. I think about this story and this world all the time, constantly wanting to know more about it. The writing of this game, as well as the dialogue is so damn good, I can think only of using the word 'professional' to describe it. The voice acting is flawless and incredibly powerful and the characters are extremely layered, believable and despite being Fables, suffer from real human problems that the player can relate to. Combined with a synthesized and memorable soundtrack that PERFECTLY creates the feeling of an 80's noir film, this game is nothing short of the word fantastic.Overall, The Wolf Among Us delivers in every way. Easily one of the coolest games I have ever played, with the Bigby character easily one of the most interesting/badass characters I have ever seen. I would highly recommend this game to anyone. I give this game a solid 9 out of 10.

Posted: July 27, 2014
												I am sure at this point you are really suspicious from any and all "player choices" in story-driven games, especially with things from Bioware ( SWtOR, Mass Effect ) and possibly Black Noire where if you make the most hatefull comment towards this 1 goon you do not like in the end the game will still "force" you to behave like best buds because the game needs to continue in some fashion, right ?Now I will not say that this game does not share any of those caracteristics, but it seems to have its stuff sorted out way better than any games I have played thusfar. I do not expect for Mr Toad to ever get his Glamour on depending on your choices or anything, but things like that do however "feel" right since Mr Toad is one of those guys you will just love to hate for his scumbag behaviour. Ofcourse you are playing as Bigby, the big bad wolf, so creating a story that really feels more interactive is probably way easier than lets say, for a blank slate. And I say they really pulled it off well.In short, ever fancied reading an interactive book while lounging back in your chair with your hands on the WADS keys and your mouse ? Pick this thing up. I played though the game once and used a guide to collect the missing "collectables" and I got 16 hours out of it. Now I know I picked it up at a Steam Sale ( Summer 2014 ) but if I knew I would have gotten this much fun out of it I would just have paid the (*checks current price*) 22.99 Euro's for it.Then again if you are not sure if you would like the game that amount of pricing might scare you off. I know I was scared off by it, especially since I never heard of Fable. Same thing with The Walking Dead, and do I really want to go Back to the Future ? If they are even remotely similar by looks and voice and general aestetics I can vouch for them, but since I am not sure if I want to play their other titles I'd really like to at least taste the atmosphere of those games, perhaps a demo of 1-2 chapters ( 1/6th or 2/6th of an episode ) with all but the "remain silent" and the least picked option availible ? Cus I'd like to try it, but I am not going to pay 22.99 Euro's just to get my feet wet and decide that the pool has too much clorine in it for my taste

Posted: December 21, 2013
												Lately I have been very impressed with Telltales works.The first season of their 'The Walking Dead' series successfully made me care for the characters and story, in such a way that I don't think that anything felt particularly forced. Of cause it has it's own share of convenience, as often seen in TV series following the same sort of formula. The way they force players to quickly take decisions, both in dialog and action sequences keeps the flow going though, even in the very few areas of 'filler'.Moving on to 'The Wolf Among us'!I were not aware of the graphic novel before I saw this game on the Steam store page, but I got hooked right from the start.The graphic style, which worked very well in 'The Walking Dead', has been improved here with a deep ink-y feel. It's like a graphic novel in motion and the overall aesthetics do a very good job at setting the tone and the colors are very pleasing too.The gameplay is very simplistic, it is basically a modernized point and click adventure. I don't count that as a negative though. It isn't the same kind of, combine chewing gum with bottle cap, then interact with door to produce advancement in plot, point and click deal, but a more modernized version, focusing on plot and the pacing of gameplay (please, Monkey Island, I mean no offence, you are still very dear in my heart). You will go through slower parts were you investigate crime scenes and engage in chase & fight scenes alike. It all seems very well paced.I really don't know what more to say right now without spoiling it for you.TotalBiscuit has a very good video about this game, and I share a lot of his opinions.

It has a pretty cool art style. I liked the Telltale Walking Dead series a lot of well but I was less familiar with Fables, so it was a brand new story and universe. I didn't know what to expect and was pleasantly surprised. Walking Dead was also an original take on a series but it wasn't a whole new universe. The story is dark and has a lot of memorable characters. Good writing and voiceover.

Posted: December 7, 2014
The Wolf Among Us is based on the DC (Vertigo) comic series Fables. The plot involves fairy tale characters living in a modern day city. Your main character Bigby Wolf has to investigate a series of gruesome murders linking to someone targeting fairy tale creatures. What unfolds is a conspiracy that will shake the foundations of their world.I love TellTale Games! Therefore i might be biased. But in all honesty, this is a damn good game.The question is should you buy it? Well, it depends on what you are looking for in a game. I personally love games for their storylines and this game gets top marks for that. The film noir-esque atmosphere, the design and environments all work in the game's favor and build an atmosphere that really complements the game's story. But, the question still remains. What do you look for in a game.Gameplay comprises of Quick time events and some point and click style stuff. You pick dialogue choices which influence the story.For those of you familiar with TTG's formula, this is nothing new. For those of you who come in expecting puzzles, you will be disappointed.This is more akin to a çhoose your own adventure book' or an interactive movie than a classic point and click game. For me, that is not a problem. The story was epic and satisfying. The characters felt alive. The action sequences well paced and your decisions can have a real impact (even on the survival of some characters).Bottomline:If you are familiar with TTG's formula and like it, or if you are looking for a game with a good story or you are a fan of the original comic series, Get the gameHowever if you are looking for a puzzle laden point and click game than this is not what it is.The game has a fair bit of replayability, just to see what different outcomes you can get, which people you can save.My Recommendation: Buy it!

Posted: July 4, 2014
												Telltale has managed to catch lightning in a bottle with their episodic adventure game series and like Walking Dead before it, Wolf Among Us is an intensely engaging rollercoaster of an experience. While in Walking Dead you are often quite aware of the effects of your actions (even if the morally objectable actions have very good justifications to keeping you and the other survivors alive), in Wolf Among Us, you must weigh reputation against efficiency, protecting the few or the many, maintaining the status quo or ultimately tearing down a flawed but well-established system...and hurting all the people that entails. Your decisions are much more morally gray, much more difficult to predict the outcomes of. In this way, it can oftentimes be a much more intense experience than Walking Dead (which in itself was incredibly intense). There is no decision to be made about which one is better, of course. They are both amazing in very different ways. But if you enjoy the comic Fables, you will enjoy this. If you enjoy "hidden world" narratives of mythical creatures living among us, you will enjoy this. If you enjoy compelling narratives surrounding intensely enjoyable and fleshed-out characters, you will enjoy this. If you enjoy Telltale's way of telling a story through these sorts of games, you will enjoy this. If you enjoy turning into a giant f***ing wolf and ripping out some dude's juggular after he hassled you for three episodes...Well, you get the picture. There is a good chance that if you breathe and have functioning eyes, you will enjoy this.

												where do i start? the graphics have a unique noire kind of look, absolutely breathtaking story, and I love how telltale games made their games revolve around what choices you make. you play as Bigby Wolf (or the big bad wolf from the stories) as a detective in fabletown, a place where all fairy tale people fit in with the mundies (what the fables call humans) by using a potion made by witches called Glamour to make the inhuman look human. but this elixer is not free, it is very expensive. two members of fabletown were murdered and Bigby Wolf will do whatever it takes to solve his case and get justice to bring a little more peace to fabletown... Posted: July 9, 2014
												A fantastic story, in a game that mix Heavy Rain with the Changelling RPG. It feels like a interactive novel, in witch most of your actions as a player are just choosing what to say, make decisions, follow one lead or the other. The combat also feels incredible, since it's highly cinematic, and plays with your sense of control over the game.The story is about Fabletown, a obscure neighbor in New York where characters from fable storys live now, after leaving the Homelands. But nothing is easy in the mundane world, so in the game most of the "happy ever after" never happened. Princes and princess got separeted, innocent girls from ancient tales hook for a living, and the Big Bad Wolf is the sheriff of the town.Now that all of the 5 chapters are out, it's really worthy buyng it, as there is no more waiting time for the next part to be produced. The final chapter is a special thing. All your actions, decisions, everything you said will have consequences when it comes down to the end.This is cinema, in a game language.

Posted: July 6, 2014
												I have to say I'm terribly pleased that Telltale Games have finally decided to compose an adventure set in this delightful universe, it must also be added that I greatly approve of the direction the company is heading. TWAU is a wonderful story that's both strangely comic and poignant; it's imbued with a sort of breezy, heart filled spirit which begins in episode one and endures throughout all the subsequent episodes. I also like that there are many ancillary characters who are unapologetic about their lack of conscience, and who don't seem to suffer in consequence. The inclusion of adult subtexts such as adultery and prostitution is a pleasant surprise to those who are unfamiliar with the comics. I've personally enjoyed the game and sincerely hope that Telltale Games continue with the franchise.9/10

Posted: November 10, 2013
												Much like The Walking Dead, "The Wolf Among Us" is based on a popular comic book series that uses many of the same features and art style. I'll be honest, I never completed TWD game, but I have a far greater urge to witness the next installment of this five part series. Once again, TellTale has gone for the interactive story style of "gameplay" and your choices affect the outcome. You "play" as Bigby Wolf(Big Bad Wolf) and attempt to solve a complex murder mystery. For a good two hours expect to mash the 'E' key repeatedly, and choose your words quickly yet carefully. If you enjoyed the "Fable" comics or looking for something similar to TWD, pick this up for $25. Though we all know how Steam is. You can always wait for a deal, or until all the episodes are released.

Posted: June 13, 2015
												Haven't reviewed this yet, eh? I best get started in light of the Summer Sale. The Wolf Among Us is another great from Telltale. It's so great in fact that it rivals their Walking Dead series and is actually quite better in a lot of ways. It takes the characters and setting from the graphic novels and really brings it all to life. So it's like this. Fairy tale creatures are living in modern day New York City. They use magical concealments called glamors to maintain human appearence. You play as Sheriff Bigby Wolf. Or as the fairy tale folk know him as, The Big Bad Wolf. You're familiar with many of the characters as you've heard about their stories before. But there's a darkness behind their backstory's and it's interesting to see how they cope with our world as they try to escape theirs. As you play you'll make tough choices, get into some crazy fights, and unravel a huge mystery. The game is short and sweet and totally worth any sale price. I highly recommend The Wolf Among Us. Especially if you enjoyed Telltales Walking Dead series.

												Wolf is another iteration of the Telltale Games studio that is more like a cirtual story, where you have some choices. It takes place in the tough world of Fables based on a DC/Vertigo comic book series. It's mature and captivating. The heroes in the series face unique challanges every day and the main character is a very likeable character, even though apparently everyone hates/ fears him. Posted: May 14, 2014
												T.W.A.U Is an amazingly deep and clever reimagining of various different Fairytale and nursery ryhme characters plots and settings compiled into a fantastically fun and well animated game. As The Fables comics are what this is based of, you can see why the unique and attractive comic book-esque graphics are used. All in all, a tense and thought provoking game about the phisolosphy of BEING a Fable,(Fairytale or nursery ryhme character living in modern day New York's "Fable Town")Plus also the game mechanic of the multi choice descisions allows for many playthroughs in different styles and ways!Totally recommended!

Posted: May 21, 2014
												I came into this not knowing anything about "Fables" or that it even existed. I simply bought this on the merit of The Walking Dead and I love the style and writing Telltale Games is going with. Let me say, that I am a bit blown-away with this game. The characters are so interesting with some excellent twists and turns in the story that is allowed because of the rich background of the game.My only gripe is that the last two episodes are considerably shorter than Telltale has demonstrated with The Walking Dead. But that's my only gripe. The writing is great and how seedy the game is with its story model really comes home scene after scene.It's also refreshing that you are actually making a difference in the order you decide to do things. You can save people by going one direction vs the other or you can miss clues by going to the wrong location.Great game. Get it.

Posted: March 11, 2014
												The Wolf Among Us has had a strong first two episodes. While not emotionally draining like The Walking Dead, it is just as well written. The characters are fully fleshed out and well acted. The user interface has been streamlined from The Walking Dead's so that you have actual dialogue boxes to select and various actions to click without needing the scroll wheel or number keys. I highly recommend this to those that liked The Walking Dead.
